cheatsheetvideos.quote: Karla only needed to Study for 1 hour. She then went to the DMV and Passed her test
DMV Test Cheat Sheet: John Tells us How to Ace The Driver’s Test On your First Try

questions.question: If you are getting tired while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop and either get rest or change drivers.
questions.answerB: Drink something with caffeine.
questions.answerC: Open a window.
questions.explanation: To avoid the dangers of fatigued driving, take breaks every hour or so during a long trip. If possible, share driving responsibilities with another person so you can each sleep while the other person drives.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Change in direction or narrowing of roadway.
questions.answerB: No right turn.
questions.answerC: No passing zone.
questions.explanation: This sign warns a driver of a change in direction or a narrowing of the road. A driver may find several of these signs on the outside of a sharp curve or on approaches to a narrow bridge.

questions.question: While in a motor vehicle on a highway, it is:
questions.answerA: Illegal to either drink from or possess open containers of alcohol.
questions.answerB: Legal to drink alcohol if you're not driving.
questions.answerC: Legal to drink alcohol if you're driving but not drunk.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol. Neither drivers nor passengers may possess an open container of alcohol in a motor vehicle while it is in operation.

questions.question: If you approach a flashing red traffic light, you:
questions.answerA: Are traveling in the wrong direction.
questions.answerB: Must treat the intersection as if it is controlled by a stop sign.
questions.answerC: May not proceed until it changes to green.
questions.explanation: Treat a flashing red light the same as a stop sign. Come to a complete stop at the stop line or, if there is no stop line, prior to the crosswalk and before entering the intersection. Yield to all other traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: This sign means you are approaching a railroad crossing that does not have a signal. You should:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Proceed at a consistent speed while looking and listening for approaching trains.
questions.answerC: Slow down, look both ways, listen for any trains, and be prepared to stop if any trains are nearby.
questions.explanation: At a railroad crossing marked with this sign, a driver should look both ways, listen for any trains, and be prepared to stop if any trains are nearby. Never try to outdrive an oncoming train.

questions.question: When stopped for a traffic violation, a driver must produce:
questions.answerA: Only their insurance and registration.
questions.answerB: Only their license.
questions.answerC: Their license, insurance, and registration.
questions.explanation: When stopped for a traffic violation, a driver must produce their license, proof of registration, and proof of insurance. Drivers are required to have all three of these documents in a vehicle any time it is being driven.

questions.question: Which of the following driving skills is/are affected by the use of alcohol and/or drugs?
questions.answerA: Alertness.
questions.answerB: Coordination.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Alcohol and other drugs can negatively effect a number of skills needed for safe driving, including a driver's reaction time, coordination, alertness, and ability to concentrate.

questions.question: The center of the roadway is marked with one solid yellow line and one broken yellow line. If the broken yellow line is directly next to your traffic lane, it means:
questions.answerA: You are not allowed to pass in this area.
questions.answerB: You are in a passing zone and it is safe for you to pass other vehicles on the left if no oncoming traffic is present.
questions.answerC: You are only allowed to make right turns in this area.
questions.explanation: When there is a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line in the center of the road, passing is permitted from the side of the road next to the broken line.

questions.question: When may drivers stop in travel lanes?
questions.answerA: When they're lost.
questions.answerB: When they are dropping off a passenger.
questions.answerC: Never.
questions.explanation: Do not stop in travel lanes for any reason (confusion, breakdown, letting out a passenger, etc.). Keep moving until you can safely pull off the road.

questions.question: Fatigue increases the risk of:
questions.answerA: Missing an exit.
questions.answerB: Being late for an appointment.
questions.answerC: Falling asleep behind the wheel and crashing.
questions.explanation: Fatigue causes errors related to speed and distance, increases your risk of being in a crash, and causes you to take more time to make decisions. When you are fatigued, you could fall asleep behind the wheel and crash, injuring or killing yourself or others.

questions.question: Drivers should use their high beam headlights:
questions.answerA: Where there are no oncoming vehicles.
questions.answerB: Where there may be pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: High beam headlights let you see twice as far as low beam headlights. It is important to use high beams on unfamiliar roads, in construction areas, or where there may be people along the side of the road. Only use high beams if other vehicles are not nearby.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow down; curving road ahead.
questions.answerB: Slow down and do not use your brakes.
questions.answerC: Slow down; slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that the road ahead becomes slippery when wet.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Railroad ahead.
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: School zone.
questions.explanation: A round yellow sign indicates that there is a railroad crossing ahead.

questions.question: As you approach the top of a hill, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up slightly.
questions.answerB: Prepare to stop, if needed.
questions.answerC: Maintain a steady speed.
questions.explanation: You may not know what is on the other side of a hill or just around a curve, even if you have driven the road many times. If a vehicle is stalled just out of sight on the roadway, you must be able to stop. Whenever you come to a hill or curve, adjust your speed so you can stop if necessary.

questions.question: You are approaching an intersection at the posted speed limit when the signal turns yellow. You should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed through the intersection without caution.
questions.answerB: Speed up to cross the intersection before the light turns red.
questions.answerC: Stop before entering the intersection, if you can do so safely.
questions.explanation: A solid yellow light means "caution" and signals that the light will soon turn red. You should stop at a solid yellow light if you can do so safely; otherwise, you should cautiously cross the intersection.

questions.question: A driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume all drivers automatically obey the right-of-way rules.
questions.answerB: Assume most drivers obey the right-of-way rules.
questions.answerC: Always be prepared to yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: Although the right-of-way rules provide a guide to determine who should yield the right-of-way at an intersection, no one should assume they automatically have the right-of-way. The situation and circumstances at an intersection must always be considered. Drivers should yield their legal right-of-way if it can help prevent a collision.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about changing lanes?
questions.answerA: You only need to turn and look over your right shoulder for lane changes to the right or left.
questions.answerB: Look over your right shoulder for a right lane change and your left shoulder for a left lane change.
questions.answerC: Vehicles with two outside mirrors do not have blind spots.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, signal, look in all your mirrors, and look over your left or right shoulder to make sure the lane next to you is clear. Looking over your shoulder is a way to check your blind spot to be sure there is no vehicle, motorcycle, or bicycle traffic in the next lane.

questions.question: Reaction time is slower after:
questions.answerA: Drinking alcohol.
questions.answerB: Sleeping.
questions.answerC: Working hard.
questions.explanation: Alcohol slows your reflexes and reaction time, reduces your ability to see clearly, and makes you less alert. As the amount of alcohol in your body increases, your judgment worsens and your driving skills decrease. You will have trouble judging distances, speeds, and the movement of other vehicles.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Road widens ahead.
questions.answerB: Lane reduction. The right lane ends soon and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerC: Highway entrance ramp ahead.
questions.explanation: A warning sign is usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns that the number of lanes ahead is reduced and that traffic will need to merge to the left.

questions.question: What message will be found on this yellow pennant-shaped sign?
questions.answerA: Right turns only.
questions.answerB: Right turns permitted.
questions.answerC: No passing zone.
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped yellow signs like this are used to indicate a no passing zone.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Pass the vehicle as slowly as possible.
questions.answerB: Drive at the same speed as the vehicle you are passing.
questions.answerC: Pass the vehicle as safely and as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle that is traveling in the same direction as you, pass quickly to resume visibility. Return to your previous lane only when you can see both of the vehicle's headlights in your rearview mirror.

questions.question: Blind spots are:
questions.answerA: Spots in your vision when you become fatigued.
questions.answerB: Areas of the road that cannot be seen in a vehicle's mirrors.
questions.answerC: Traffic control devices.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move. Check for obstructions near the rear corners of your vehicle. These areas are called “blind spots” because you cannot see them by using your mirrors.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a safe driving practice when driving on the interstate?
questions.answerA: Slower traffic must keep to the right.
questions.answerB: Change lanes without signaling.
questions.answerC: If you miss your exit, you must go to the next exit.
questions.explanation: You should always signal when moving your vehicle to the right or left. On an interstate, you should stay in the right lane if you are moving more slowly than the surrounding traffic. It is illegal to back up or make a U-turn on interstate highways, so if you miss your exit, you should proceed to the next exit.

questions.question: Yellow lines separate:
questions.answerA: Traffic lanes on one-way streets.
questions.answerB: Traffic moving in opposite directions on two-way roads.
questions.answerC: All carpool lanes from regular traffic lanes.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines mark the center of a road used for two-way traffic. A solid yellow centerline indicates that drivers may not cross the line to pass. A broken yellow centerline indicates that drivers may cross the line to pass, but only if passing would not interfere with traffic.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: Be ready to merge with traffic entering your lane.
questions.answerB: Always stop.
questions.answerC: Divided highway ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns that merging traffic will be entering from the right, so drivers should prepare to allow the incoming traffic to safely merge.

questions.question: As you enter into a roundabout, you should slow down and:
questions.answerA: Yield to any crossing pedestrians and bicyclists.
questions.answerB: Yield to any car already within the roundabout.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: When entering a roundabout, you must yield to pedestrians, bicyclists, and traffic already in the roundabout.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and use your low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Slow down and use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights on and off to warn other drivers.
questions.explanation: When driving in fog, you should slow down and use your low beam headlights. If the fog is so bad that you cannot see, pull off the road and wait for the fog to clear.

questions.question: When may you drive on the shoulder of the road?
questions.answerA: Only when told to do so by an official.
questions.answerB: When the car in front of you is driving too slowly.
questions.answerC: When the car in front of you is turning.
questions.explanation: If you pass on the right, do so only when conditions permit you to do so legally and safely. You may only drive on the shoulder of a road if an official has directed you to do so.

questions.question: When you are facing a green light and there are pedestrians in the intersection:
questions.answerA: You must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians.
questions.answerB: You have the right-of-way over pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians must wait for you to cross.
questions.explanation: When facing a green light, you must yield to pedestrians and vehicles already in the intersection. Drivers must yield to pedestrians when turning on a steady green signal.

questions.question: As you approach an intersection with a flashing yellow light:
questions.answerA: Stop before crossing the intersection.
questions.answerB: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Wait for a green light before proceeding.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light means that you should slow down, check for cross traffic, and proceed with caution.

questions.question: If you become drowsy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to fight it.
questions.answerB: Take a break.
questions.answerC: Take some caffeine pills.
questions.explanation: If you start to feel tired while driving, drive to the first available rest stop or service area to take a break, nap, stretch, or change drivers. You should not rely on caffeine pills or energy drinks, as these are not a replacement for rest and may make your driving even more dangerous.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerA: 0.05 percent.
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: When making a right turn, you should not:
questions.answerA: Signal to other drivers.
questions.answerB: Swing too wide for your lane.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: When turning right, you should slow down and activate your turn signal before making the turn. Be careful not to turn too wide for your lane, as this may interfere with traffic.

questions.question: Refusing to take an alcohol analysis test when requested to do so by law enforcement:
questions.answerA: Will result in license suspension.
questions.answerB: Is your right and will have no negative consequences.
questions.answerC: Is recommended.
questions.explanation: If you are driving a motor vehicle in South Dakota, you automatically consent to a test determining the presence of alcohol, or any other abused controlled substance, in your blood. If you refuse to submit to the test, your driving privileges will be suspended.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Do not enter.
questions.answerB: Stop ahead.
questions.answerC: Roadwork or maintenance is present.
questions.explanation: Orange, diamond-shaped signs are used to mark construction, maintenance, survey, and utility work areas. These signs help direct drivers and pedestrians safely through dangerous zones. Fines for traffic convictions may double in areas marked by these signs.

questions.question: You use your horn:
questions.answerA: Whenever it may help prevent a collision.
questions.answerB: To get other drivers moving in a traffic jam.
questions.answerC: When you're angry with another driver.
questions.explanation: Other drivers cannot see you unless they are looking your way. Your horn may get their attention. Use it whenever it will help prevent a collision.

questions.question: If a truck or bus is making a right turn where you also need to make a right turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly turn before the truck or bus is able to.
questions.answerB: Wait until the truck or bus turns before you turn.
questions.answerC: Squeeze between the truck or bus and the curb.
questions.explanation: If you try to insert your vehicle between a turning truck or bus and a curb, you may suffer a serious crash. To avoid a collision, do not turn until the truck or bus has completed its turn.

questions.question: Trucks' blind spots are:
questions.answerA: Directly behind the body.
questions.answerB: On the immediate left of the cab.
questions.answerC: Both on the immediate left of the cab and directly behind the body.
questions.explanation: A truck's blind spots are much larger than a smaller car’s blind spots. The driver cannot see your car behind their vehicle and you can't see what’s happening in traffic ahead if you're driving too closely behind the truck. Whether you are driving behind or to the side of the truck, if you can’t see the driver’s face in their side view mirror, then they can’t see you.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You must travel through the intersection at the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: The maximum speed limit under ideal conditions is 55 mph.
questions.answerC: You must not travel below the speed indicated.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs provide notice to road users of traffic laws that must be obeyed. This particular sign tells you the maximum speed limit for the stretch of highway where it is posted. You may drive more slowly than the posted speed limit, based on road conditions, but it is illegal to drive any faster than the posted speed limit.

questions.question: A U-turn is not permitted:
questions.answerA: In a parking lot.
questions.answerB: On or near any curve or hill.
questions.answerC: On a straight roadway with a clear view for 500 feet in both directions.
questions.explanation: You must never turn around while on or near any curve or hill. You may not be able to see oncoming traffic or pedestrians and may cause a collision.

questions.question: Before you enter an intersection, you should look to your:
questions.answerA: Left, your right, then your left again.
questions.answerB: Right.
questions.answerC: Left.
questions.explanation: Before you enter an intersection, look to both the left and right for approaching vehicles or crossing pedestrians. Look to your left a second time, as vehicle approaching from your left will be closer than those approaching from your right. Look across the intersection before you start to move to make sure the path is clear all the way through.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about drugs and driving?
questions.answerA: Any prescription drug is safe to use if you don't feel drowsy.
questions.answerB: Even over-the-counter drugs can impair your driving.
questions.answerC: Only illegal drugs can impair your driving.
questions.explanation: Legal prescription and over-the-counter drugs can impair your ability to drive, including drugs taken for colds, hay fever, allergies, or to calm nerves or muscles. It is illegal to drive while under the influence of any drug that impairs your ability to drive safely; this law does not differentiate between illegal, prescription, or over-the-counter drugs.

questions.question: If you find that the roadway ahead of you is flooded, you should:
questions.answerA: Slam on the brakes.
questions.answerB: Not drive through the flooded area. Turn around and find another route.
questions.answerC: Drive only in the center of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Never attempt to drive on a flooded road. Even if the water looks shallow, it may hide many kinds of hazards. If you encounter a flooded area, turn around and seek another route to your destination.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Bicycle crossing.
questions.answerB: Stop only if other cars are approaching.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way to pedestrians.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. These signs alert drivers to areas where bicycles may be crossing.

questions.question: Before stopping your vehicle at a traffic signal or sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Press down hard on the accelerator.
questions.answerB: Check your mirrors for surrounding traffic.
questions.answerC: Set the parking brake.
questions.explanation: When stopping your vehicle on the roadway, first check your mirrors for traffic. Be aware of surrounding drivers as you release the accelerator and allow your vehicle to slow. Move your foot to the brake pedal and press with steady pressure for a smooth stop.

questions.question: A curb painted red means:
questions.answerA: Loading zone.
questions.answerB: The area is reserved for picking up or dropping off passengers.
questions.answerC: No parking, standing, or stopping.
questions.explanation: You may not stop, stand, or park at a red-painted curb.

questions.question: Drivers may not park within ____ of a fire hydrant.
questions.answerA: 15 feet
questions.answerB: 20 feet
questions.answerC: 30 feet
questions.explanation: There are many areas where you cannot park. You should not park within 15 feet of a fire hydrant.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: Slow down and prepare to stop if cars are approaching you.
questions.answerB: Come to a full stop then proceed when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Proceed carefully through the intersection, not always stopping.
questions.explanation: An octagonal sign always means stop. When approaching a stop sign, you must come to a complete stop at the marked stop line and proceed only when it is safe to do so. If there is no stop line, stop before the crosswalk. If there is no crosswalk, stop before the intersection at a point from which you can see any oncoming traffic.

questions.question: This sign tells you that:
questions.answerA: No turns are allowed on the road.
questions.answerB: The road narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: There is a series of curves ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers about an upcoming winding road.

questions.question: When making a left turn, you should not:
questions.answerA: Signal to other drivers.
questions.answerB: Cut the corner.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: When turning left, you should slow down and activate your turn signal before making the turn. Be careful not to cut the corner short, as this may interfere with traffic.

questions.question: You want to park downhill on a two-way road and there is no curb. Which way do you turn your front wheels?
questions.answerA: Straight ahead
questions.answerB: Right, toward the side of the road
questions.answerC: Left, toward the center of the road
questions.explanation: When parking facing downhill on a road with or without a curb, or when facing uphill on a road without a curb, turn your front wheels toward the edge of the road so your vehicle will roll away from traffic if the brakes fail. However, when parking uphill on a road with a curb, turn your wheels toward the center of the road so the vehicle will roll into the curb if the brakes fail.

questions.question: A diamond-shaped sign means:
questions.answerA: Yield.
questions.answerB: Stop.
questions.answerC: Warning.
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs are used to warn drivers of special conditions or hazards ahead. They are typically yellow or orange in color.

questions.question: A red arrow pointing to the right on a traffic light means you may:
questions.answerA: Turn in that direction after slowing and checking for traffic.
questions.answerB: Not turn in that direction until the light turns green.
questions.answerC: Turn in that direction after you come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A red arrow means "stop." You must remain stopped until a green light or green arrow appears. Do not turn against a red arrow.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the thinking of defensive drivers?
questions.answerA: They know other drivers will do the right thing.
questions.answerB: They consider what other drivers might do and are prepared to react.
questions.answerC: They expect no breaks and give none.
questions.explanation: Driving defensively means anticipating potential errors made by others and preparing to compensate for their mistakes.

questions.question: Only ____ can lower blood alcohol concentration (BAC) and reduce alcohol's effects on a body.
questions.answerA: Drinking caffeine
questions.answerB: Eating foods high in fat
questions.answerC: Time
questions.explanation: The only way to sober up after drinking alcohol is to allow time for your body to eliminate the alcohol in your system. Nothing you can do, including eating and drinking, can accelerate this process.

questions.question: If you have had several beers, the effects of alcohol will be reduced only by:
questions.answerA: Taking a cold shower.
questions.answerB: Waiting several hours.
questions.answerC: Drinking several cups of coffee.
questions.explanation: The only way to remove the impairing effects of alcohol is to give the body time to remove it from the body. Drinking coffee, physical activity, or taking a cold shower will not speed up this process. It takes about one hour to cancel the effects of one drink.

questions.question: There are oncoming vehicles to your left and a row of parked vehicles to your right. You should steer:
questions.answerA: Closer to the oncoming vehicles than the parked vehicles.
questions.answerB: Closer to the parked vehicles than the oncoming vehicles.
questions.answerC: A middle course between the oncoming and parked vehicles.
questions.explanation: If there are oncoming vehicles to your left and a row of parked vehicles to your right, the best thing to do is to split the difference. Steer a middle course between the oncoming cars and the parked cars.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Use your parking lights.
questions.answerC: Use your low beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Drivers should use low beam headlights when driving in fog. High beams will reflect back at the driver, making it difficult to see.

questions.question: When entering traffic after being parked at a curb, you:
questions.answerA: Should drive more slowly than other traffic for 200 feet.
questions.answerB: Should wait for a large enough gap to get up to the speed of traffic.
questions.answerC: Should wait for the first two vehicles to pass, then drive into the lane.
questions.explanation: Any time that you merge into city or highway traffic, you should wait for a gap in traffic large enough for your vehicle to get up to the speed of other traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrians walking along the road ahead.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians must not cross here.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to where pedestrians may be crossing. If a pedestrian is crossing in a crosswalk marked with this sign, drivers must stop and remain stopped until the pedestrian is no longer in the crosswalk.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: Winding road
questions.answerB: Loose gravel
questions.answerC: Slippery when wet
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road may be slippery when wet. Exercise caution when driving on a slippery road.

questions.question: This yellow warning sign means:
questions.answerA: You are approaching a school or school crosswalk.
questions.answerB: Slow down, drive with caution, and watch for children.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: This sign is placed on roads near schools to warn drivers to slow down, drive with caution, and watch for children.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No right turn.
questions.answerB: You must turn right.
questions.answerC: Watch for traffic on your right.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits right turns. You cannot make a right turn at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: Driving under the influence of any medication which impairs your driving is permitted:
questions.answerA: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerB: If you don't feel drowsy.
questions.answerC: If it is prescribed by a physician.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to drive under the influence of any substance that impairs your ability to drive safely. This includes alcohol, prescription medications, over-the-counter medications, and illegal drugs.

questions.question: A broken yellow line beside a solid yellow line indicates that passing is:
questions.answerA: Permitted from the side next to the solid yellow line.
questions.answerB: Not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerC: Permitted from the side next to the broken yellow line.
questions.explanation: When the center of the road is marked by a solid yellow line beside a broken yellow line, passing is permitted from the side next to the broken line and prohibited from the side next to the solid line.

questions.question: If a tire blows out, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brake and hold it.
questions.answerB: Hold the steering wheel tightly and use the brakes lightly.
questions.answerC: Pull over quickly.
questions.explanation: If a tire suddenly blows out while you are driving, hold the steering wheel tightly and keep the vehicle going straight.You should slow down gradually, taking your foot off the gas pedal and using the brakes lightly. Do not stop on the road if at all possible. Pull off the road in a safe place.

questions.question: Water on the road can cause a vehicle to hydroplane. Your car may hydroplane at speeds as low as:
questions.answerA: 45 miles per hour.
questions.answerB: 35 miles per hour.
questions.answerC: 40 miles per hour.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning occurs when there is standing water on a roadway. At speeds up to 35 mph, most tires will channel water away from the tire. As your speed increases past 35 mph, tires cannot channel the water as well and your tires may start to lose contact with the road and ride over the water like a set of water skis.

questions.question: This yellow sign means:
questions.answerA: There is a sharp turn to the right.
questions.answerB: The lane must turn right.
questions.answerC: A right turn is permitted on a green arrow only.
questions.explanation: Some warning signs have a fluorescent yellow-green background. These signs warn of upcoming conditions, including roads with curves and sharp turns.

questions.question: Handicap parking spaces are available:
questions.answerA: To anyone, but only if all other spaces are occupied.
questions.answerB: Only to drivers with the appropriate license plate or hanging tag.
questions.answerC: To people who are not feeling well.
questions.explanation: Reserved handicap parking spaces should be used only by persons with a disability as defined under state law. To park in a handicap parking space, you must have either the appropriate license plate or designated hang tag displaying the international symbol.

questions.question: When a pedestrian guided by a dog or carrying a white cane is crossing the street:
questions.answerA: You must always yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: You must tell them where to cross the street.
questions.answerC: You only have to yield the right-of-way if you are at a corner.
questions.explanation: Blind or partially blind pedestrians may carry a white cane or use the assistance of a guide dog. You must always yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian who is using a guide dog or carrying a white cane.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Yield sign ahead.
questions.answerB: Side road entering from left.
questions.answerC: Stop sign ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a yield sign ahead. You should begin to slow down when you see this warning sign.

questions.question: Which lane must you be in before making a left turn from a one-way street?
questions.answerA: The lane nearest the left curb.
questions.answerB: The lane nearest the center of the street.
questions.answerC: The lane nearest the right curb.
questions.explanation: When making any turn, turn from the lane closest to the direction you wish to travel into the first available legal lane. If you are making a left turn from a one-way street, this means that you would make the turn from the lane nearest to the left curb.

questions.question: A flashing yellow light at an intersection means you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Stop and proceed only when the intersection is clear.
questions.explanation: When encountering a flashing yellow light at an intersection, you should slow down and proceed with caution. You do not need to come to a complete stop when approaching a flashing yellow light.

questions.question: When driving in work zones, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to get through the zone as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed and be prepared to stop suddenly.
questions.answerC: Maintain your normal speed the whole way through the zone.
questions.explanation: When entering and driving through a work zone, slow down and be prepared to stop. Obey posted speed limits and be alert to conditions around you. Workers could be present.

questions.question: To avoid traction loss on wet roads, you should:
questions.answerA: Make abrupt turns.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes firmly.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: To prevent hydroplaning, lower your speed in response to wet roads and keep your tires in good condition. If you detect a loss of control, take your foot off the gas, do not apply the brakes, maintain the direction of the vehicle, and allow the vehicle to slow to a manageable speed.

questions.question: You check your blind spots:
questions.answerA: By looking in your side mirrors.
questions.answerB: By turning your head and looking over your shoulders.
questions.answerC: By looking in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Blind spots are areas around your vehicle that you cannot see by using your mirrors. Check your blind spots by turning your head and glancing over your shoulders.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Road construction ahead.
questions.answerB: The road ahead curves left then right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead curves right then left.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that the upcoming road will curve right, followed by a curve to the left. Drivers should adjust their speed to safely continue on the road.

questions.question: What message will be found on a red octagon-shaped sign?
questions.answerA: Do not enter.
questions.answerB: One-way.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: An octagonal (eight-sided) sign always means "stop." You must always come to a complete stop at this sign.

questions.question: If you park facing uphill on a street with a curb, set the parking brake and:
questions.answerA: Turn the front wheels toward the curb.
questions.answerB: Turn the front wheels away from the curb.
questions.answerC: Leave the front wheels straight.
questions.explanation: When parking uphill on a road that has a curb, your wheels should be turned away from the curb. When parking uphill on a street without a curb or when parking downhill, your wheels should be turned toward the curb or edge of the road.

questions.question: When stopped at a red traffic light with a green arrow, you may proceed in the direction of the arrow if you:
questions.answerA: First come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Wait until the light changes.
questions.answerC: Are in the proper lane and the intersection is clear.
questions.explanation: You may proceed in the direction that a green arrow signal is pointing if you are in the proper lane, regardless of any other signals that are displayed. Before turning, you must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and vehicles already within the intersection.

questions.question: To help avoid skidding on slippery surfaces, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift to a lower gear after starting down a steep hill.
questions.answerB: Speed up to enter curves and slow down to exit them.
questions.answerC: Slow down before entering curves and intersections.
questions.explanation: Slow down before you enter a curve because you do not know what may be ahead. Braking on a curve may cause you to skid.

questions.question: When you approach an octagonal sign, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow.
questions.answerB: Stop.
questions.answerC: Turn.
questions.explanation: An octagonal (eight-sided) sign always means "Stop." Come to a complete stop, yield to traffic and pedestrians that have the right-of-way, and proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: You are on the freeway and traffic is merging into your lane. You should:
questions.answerA: Make room for the merging traffic, if possible.
questions.answerB: Assert your right-of-way by driving faster.
questions.answerC: Always maintain your position.
questions.explanation: When traffic permits, you should make room to allow vehicles to merge into your lane.

questions.question: Regulatory signs are:
questions.answerA: Green.
questions.answerB: Yellow.
questions.answerC: White.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs inform drivers of specific laws that must be obeyed. Displayed laws may be about traffic direction, lane use, turning, speed, parking, or special situations. Regulatory signs are commonly white squares or rectangles with black, red, or green letters or symbols.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Cars in the right lane must slow down.
questions.answerB: No left turn.
questions.answerC: Merge.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that there could be traffic merging from the right, so drivers should prepare to allow traffic to safely merge.

questions.question: When driving in work zones, you should:
questions.answerA: Follow the driver in front of you closely.
questions.answerB: Pass the driver in front of you as soon as you can.
questions.answerC: Avoid tailgating and keep a safe following distance.
questions.explanation: When driving in a work zone, keep a safe distance between your vehicle and traffic barriers, trucks, construction equipment, workers, and other vehicles. Increase your following distance and do not tailgate.

questions.question: When turning left at an intersection:
questions.answerA: You should always yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Oncoming traffic and pedestrians should yield to you.
questions.answerC: You should never yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.explanation: Drivers making left turns must yield to oncoming traffic that is traveling straight. Drivers must always yield to pedestrians.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: School zone or crossing.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerC: Railroad ahead.
questions.explanation: A five-sided yellow or yellow-green sign alerts drivers to either a school zone or school crossing.

questions.question: At a crosswalk:
questions.answerA: You must yield to pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Pedestrians must yield to you.
questions.answerC: Construction workers must yield to you.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians have the right-of-way at street crossings but must obey traffic control signals. Where a traffic signal is not present, vehicles must stop for pedestrians in a crosswalk, whether it is marked or unmarked.

questions.question: Which statement is true?
questions.answerA: You should put on your cruise control near a railroad crossing to maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerB: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign.
questions.answerC: You have the right-of-way at a railroad crossing and do not need to stop.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger, stop sign, or warning signal. Use caution when driving near railroad tracks.

questions.question: It is more dangerous to drive at night than during the day because:
questions.answerA: You cannot see as far ahead at night.
questions.answerB: The road is always more slippery at night.
questions.answerC: Your reaction time is slower at night.
questions.explanation: With decreased visibility and the glare of oncoming headlights, you cannot see as far ahead at night as you can during the day. Always use headlights and exercise caution when driving in the dark.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Merge right.
questions.answerB: Divided highway begins.
questions.answerC: Lane ends.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the right lane ends ahead. A merging maneuver will be required for drivers in that lane.

questions.question: At intersections with a "Yield" sign, you must:
questions.answerA: Yield the right-of-way to cross traffic that is near enough to cause conflict.
questions.answerB: Yield the right-of-way only to vehicles on your right.
questions.answerC: Always slow down and proceed without stopping.
questions.explanation: At a yield sign, you must slow down or stop, if necessary, and give the right-of-way to crossing or merging vehicles. Yield the right-of-way to any cross traffic that is close enough to cause conflict.

questions.question: Accumulating ____ on your license within a 24-month period will result in the suspension of your license.
questions.answerA: 15 points
questions.answerB: 22 points
questions.answerC: 30 points
questions.explanation: Certain offenses committed while driving will count against a driver in South Dakota's system of suspending driver licenses. If a driver accrues 22 points or more within a 24-month period, their license will be suspended. Lengths of suspension vary based on how many offenses the driver has committed.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerB: Merging traffic.
questions.answerC: Steep hill ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers of an upcoming steep hill. Drivers should adjust their speed accordingly to avoid collisions and brake damage.

questions.question: If pedestrians are illegally crossing in the middle of the street instead of in a crosswalk, you:
questions.answerA: Must stop for them.
questions.answerB: Do not have to stop for them.
questions.answerC: Should honk your horn at them.
questions.explanation: You must yield to pedestrians at all times. If the pedestrians are jaywalking or crossing the street where they should not be, you must still stop for them.

questions.question: You see pedestrians near the road. You should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn and maintain your speed.
questions.answerB: Speed up to clear the area quickly.
questions.answerC: Slow down and pass with caution.
questions.explanation: Watch for any pedestrian who may cross your path. If you see pedestrians near the road where you are driving, slow down and be prepared to stop, if necessary.

questions.question: You may legally block an intersection:
questions.answerA: If you entered the intersection on the green light.
questions.answerB: During rush hour traffic.
questions.answerC: Under no circumstances.
questions.explanation: Even if the light is green, you may not enter an intersection unless you can get completely across before the light turns red. If you block the intersection, you can be cited.

questions.question: When driving in fog, it is best to drive with:
questions.answerA: High beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: Use low beam headlights when driving in fog, rain, or snow. High beams may reflect off of the weather and make visibility even poorer.

questions.question: At a red traffic light with a green arrow, you may proceed in the direction of the arrow if:
questions.answerA: You first come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: You wait until the light changes.
questions.answerC: You are in the proper lane and the roadway is clear.
questions.explanation: If you are in a lane corresponding to a signal displaying a green arrow, you may proceed in the direction of the arrow when the way is clear. This is true whether the arrow is displayed alone or together with another signal.

questions.question: Backing your vehicle is:
questions.answerA: Always dangerous.
questions.answerB: Dangerous if you have a helper.
questions.answerC: Only dangerous in large vehicles.
questions.explanation: Backing up is always dangerous because it is hard to see behind your vehicle. Use extra caution when backing up.

questions.question: This sign indicates a:
questions.answerA: Railroad crossing.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerC: No passing zone.
questions.explanation: Yellow signs with black markings are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazards or special conditions. Round signs are used only to warn about upcoming railroad crossings.

questions.question: South Dakota law requires ____ to use safety belts in a moving vehicle.
questions.answerA: Only operators
questions.answerB: Only children
questions.answerC: Children, front seat passengers, and operators
questions.explanation: The law requires all operators, front seat passengers, and children under the age of 18 to wear appropriate safety restraints while a vehicle is in motion. Small children should be secured in the rear seat.

questions.question: When a bicyclist is making a left turn:
questions.answerA: They may use the left lane.
questions.answerB: They may cut through all lanes.
questions.answerC: They may wait on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: You should expect to see bicyclists driving with traffic on the road. You should not be surprised to see a bicyclist using the left lane when turning.

questions.question: You should use your horn when:
questions.answerA: Another vehicle is in your way.
questions.answerB: It may help prevent a collision.
questions.answerC: Another driver makes a mistake.
questions.explanation: Only use your horn when it is necessary to avoid collisions. Do not use your horn if a driver or bicyclist is moving slowly and you want him or her to drive faster or get out of your way.

questions.question: What should you do with loose objects in your motor vehicle?
questions.answerA: Place them on the floor near the driver's seat.
questions.answerB: Secure them to avoid additional driving hazards.
questions.answerC: Place them on the dashboard.
questions.explanation: Make sure there are no loose objects in your vehicle that could hit and injure someone in the event of a sudden stop or crash. Make sure there are no objects on the floor that could roll under the brake pedal and prevent you from stopping the vehicle.

questions.question: It is legal to make a left turn at a red traffic light after stopping only if:
questions.answerA: You are traveling on a two-way street and turning onto a two-way street.
questions.answerB: You are traveling on a one-way street and turning onto another one-way street.
questions.answerC: You yield to all other traffic at the intersection.
questions.explanation: After coming to a complete stop, you may turn left at a red light only if you are traveling on a one-way street and turning onto another one-way street. Only make the turn if there are no posted signs prohibiting such a turn.

questions.question: When used on roadways, bicycles are considered:
questions.answerA: Hazards.
questions.answerB: Vehicles.
questions.answerC: Dangerous.
questions.explanation: Bicycles are considered vehicles when used on roadways. Bicyclists and motorists are expected to follow the same rules of the road.

questions.question: When driving under snowy or icy conditions:
questions.answerA: It is safe to use your cruise control.
questions.answerB: Make speed and directional changes more gradually than you would otherwise.
questions.answerC: Drive as you would under normal conditions.
questions.explanation: When driving under snowy or icy conditions, you should make speed and directional changes gradually. Never use cruise control when driving on snow or ice because your tires may lose contact with the road and you will lose control of your vehicle.

questions.question: Work zone barriers, drums, cones, and signs are used to:
questions.answerA: Make drivers angry about slow traffic.
questions.answerB: Inconvenience drivers.
questions.answerC: Keep traffic out of hazardous work zones.
questions.explanation: Work zones on highways have become increasingly dangerous places for both workers and drivers. When approaching a work zone, watch for materials such as cones, barrels, signs, large vehicles, and workers in brightly colored vests to warn you and direct you.

questions.question: Double solid yellow line markings down the center of a road indicate that passing is:
questions.answerA: Allowed from both directions.
questions.answerB: Allowed only from your direction of travel.
questions.answerC: Not allowed from either direction.
questions.explanation: A double yellow centerline means that it is prohibited for traffic from either direction to cross the centerline to pass.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: All traffic must turn right.
questions.answerB: All traffic must go straight.
questions.answerC: A side road intersects ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This warning sign tells drivers to be alert to an intersecting side road ahead.

questions.question: Which of the following is a dangerous habit when driving in work zones?
questions.answerA: Tailgating another vehicle
questions.answerB: Failing to carefully watch for workers and moving equipment
questions.answerC: Both of the above
questions.explanation: When driving in a work zone, adjust your speed for the traffic conditions and don't follow other vehicles too closely. Be attentive to workers and machines in the work zone.

questions.question: Before changing lanes or attempting to pass another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Check your blind spots and mirrors.
questions.answerB: Signal your intention before changing lanes.
questions.answerC: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Every time you want to change lanes or otherwise move your vehicle to the right or left, signal to alert other drivers to your intentions. Always check your mirrors and turn your head to check your blind spot before attempting any lateral move.

questions.question: If you are driving and a tire suddenly goes flat, you should:
questions.answerA: Rapidly pump the brake pedal several times.
questions.answerB: Slow down gradually and not brake.
questions.answerC: Press down on the brake pedal as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: If a tire blows out or suddenly goes flat while you are driving, grip the steering wheel firmly and keep the vehicle aiming straight. Take your foot off the accelerator and do not brake. Allow the vehicle to slow by itself and use the brakes gently, but only if necessary. Pull off the road when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When entering or exiting a driveway, drivers:
questions.answerA: Have the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Should yield to pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Should honk at pedestrians to get them to move more quickly.
questions.explanation: Drivers crossing a sidewalk when entering or exiting a driveway, alley, or parking lot must yield to pedestrians. It is illegal to drive on a sidewalk except to cross it.

questions.question: Stopping distances and severity of crashes:
questions.answerA: Decrease as vehicle speed increases.
questions.answerB: Are not affected by vehicle speed.
questions.answerC: Increase as vehicle speed increases.
questions.explanation: Stopping distances are longer and crashes are more severe when traffic travels at higher speeds.

questions.question: If you come to a railroad crossing with lowered gates and flashing warning lights, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive around the crossing gates if you can't see a train.
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop well behind the gates, wait for the tracks to clear, and proceed once the gates are lifted.
questions.answerC: Slow down and drive around the gates.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing where signs, warning devices, or flaggers warn you of the presence of a train. It is illegal to drive around lowered gates.

questions.question: This sign indicates:
questions.answerA: The distance from road surface to a bridge or overpass.
questions.answerB: The maximum legal height of a vehicle allowed in this state.
questions.answerC: The maximum width of a vehicle allowed on the highway.
questions.explanation: This is a low clearance warning sign. It indicates the distance from the road surface to the bottom of a bridge or overpass (in this case, 12 feet, 6 inches).

questions.question: When driving down a long or steep hill, you should:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors for speeding traffic behind you.
questions.answerB: Assume all traffic is maintaining a consistent speed.
questions.answerC: Hold down your brake pedal to control the speed of surrounding traffic.
questions.explanation: Check your mirrors for quickly approaching vehicles when you are driving down hills or mountains. Vehicles often build up speed while traveling down a steep grade. Be alert to large trucks and buses that may be going too fast.

questions.question: Slowing down just to look at collisions or anything else out-of-the-ordinary:
questions.answerA: Causes traffic congestion.
questions.answerB: Prevents rear-end collisions.
questions.answerC: Improves traffic flow by preventing collisions.
questions.explanation: Avoid "rubbernecking," or slowing down to look at collisions or anything else out-of-the-ordinary. This helps to relieve traffic congestion.

questions.question: When driving under low-visibility conditions due to fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on your high beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Slow down and use your low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed so you do not cause an accident.
questions.explanation: When driving in fog, you should slow down and use your low beam lights. If the fog is so dense that you cannot see, pull off the road and wait for the fog to clear.

questions.question: When turning left at an intersection:
questions.answerA: You should always yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Oncoming traffic and pedestrians should yield to you.
questions.answerC: You should never yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.explanation: When turning left at an intersection, yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic and pedestrians. Once the intersection is clear and applicable signals allow, you may complete the turn.

questions.question: You may pass a vehicle when:
questions.answerA: You are on a hill or curve.
questions.answerB: You are on a road with a solid line next to your lane.
questions.answerC: You are on a road with a broken line next to your lane.
questions.explanation: A single broken line indicates that drivers may cross from either lane to change lanes. Dashed yellow lines alongside solid yellow lines indicate that passing is permitted from the lane next to the broken line, but not from the lane next to the solid line. Only change lanes when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When you are merging onto the freeway, you should be driving:
questions.answerA: At or near the speed of traffic on the freeway.
questions.answerB: Five to 10 mph slower than the speed of traffic on the freeway.
questions.answerC: The posted speed limit for freeway traffic.
questions.explanation: When merging onto a freeway, you should enter at or near the speed of traffic.

questions.question: Adjust your rearview and side mirrors:
questions.answerA: Before you start driving.
questions.answerB: Whenever you need to use them.
questions.answerC: Before you get into the car.
questions.explanation: Your safety and the safety of other drivers and pedestrians depends a lot on what you do before driving. Before moving your vehicle, you should adjust your seat, adjust your mirrors, fasten your safety belt, and secure items in and on your vehicle. Do not wait until your vehicle is moving to adjust your mirrors.

questions.question: You are preparing to exit the interstate. When should you start reducing your speed?
questions.answerA: About halfway through the deceleration lane.
questions.answerB: As you approach the deceleration lane.
questions.answerC: Immediately upon entering the deceleration lane.
questions.explanation: When leaving an interstate, you should maintain your speed until you enter the deceleration lane, at which point you should reduce your speed to the exit ramp's posted advisory speed.

questions.question: When taking any medicine, you should:
questions.answerA: Consult your doctor about the effects before driving.
questions.answerB: Have someone follow you home.
questions.answerC: Keep your window open and drive more slowly.
questions.explanation: Legal medications, both prescription and over-the-counter, can potentially impair your ability to drive. Always consult with your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions about how a particular drug or drug combination will affect your ability to drive. You should particularly make a point of talking with your doctor if they give you a prescription for a tranquilizer or sedative.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Do not enter.
questions.answerB: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Reserved parking for persons with disabilities.
questions.explanation: This sign is posted on one-way streets and other roadways where a driver is not allowed to enter. A driver may see this sign if attempting to enter an expressway ramp in the wrong direction.

questions.question: If you are about to be hit from the rear, you should consider each of the following, except for:
questions.answerA: Applying your brakes.
questions.answerB: Letting go of the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Pressing your head firmly against the head restraint.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle is hit from the rear while you are in forward motion, your body will be thrown backward. Press yourself against the back of your seat and put your head against the head restraint to prevent whiplash. Maintain a firm grip on the steering wheel and be ready to apply your brakes to avoid being pushed into another vehicle.

questions.question: This sign indicates that:
questions.answerA: There is a steep hill ahead.
questions.answerB: No trucks are allowed on the upcoming hill.
questions.answerC: A logging road is ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers about an upcoming steep hill. Drivers should slow down and be ready to control their speed and protect their brakes from damage.

questions.question: This red and white sign means you should:
questions.answerA: Stop and check for traffic coming from both directions before proceeding.
questions.answerB: Give the right-of-way to traffic on the road you wish to enter or cross.
questions.answerC: Maintain a steady speed and check for traffic coming from all directions.
questions.explanation: A three-sided yield sign indicates that you must slow down and be ready to stop, if necessary, to let any vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian pass before you proceed. In this case, you do not have the right-of-way.

questions.question: Only ____ can reduce blood alcohol content (BAC) and alcohol's effects on the body.
questions.answerA: Drinking caffeine
questions.answerB: Eating foods high in fat
questions.answerC: Time
questions.explanation: Only the passage of time can remove alcohol and its impairing effects from the body.

questions.question: You want to make a right turn at the corner. A pedestrian with a guide dog is at the corner ready to cross the street in front of you. Before making your right turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn off your engine until the person crosses the street.
questions.answerB: Tell the pedestrian when to cross the street.
questions.answerC: Wait until the person crosses the street.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians using guide dogs or white canes (with or without a red tip) must be given the right-of-way at all times.

questions.question: When should you yield your legal right-of-way?
questions.answerA: Often, even at controlled intersections.
questions.answerB: Whenever it helps prevent collisions.
questions.answerC: Never. It confuses other drivers.
questions.explanation: Never assume other drivers will give you the right-of-way. Yield your right-of-way whenever it helps prevent collisions.

questions.question: Hydroplaning occurs when tires ride on a thin film of water instead of on the surface of the road. To prevent hydroplaning in rainy weather, you should:
questions.answerA: Put on your cruise control to maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerB: Decrease your speed.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder of the road as soon as it starts to rain.
questions.explanation: In rainy weather, you should lower your speed to reduce the risk of hydroplaning. Driving too fast may cause your tires to ride up on the water and lose contact with the surface of the road, making it very difficult to control your vehicle.

questions.question: Vehicles are required to be covered by liability insurance:
questions.answerA: Only when used on an interstate.
questions.answerB: Only when operated by a minor.
questions.answerC: At all times.
questions.explanation: South Dakota state law requires all vehicles to be properly registered and insured at all times. Drivers must keep proof of responsibility in the vehicle.

questions.question: You are driving on the freeway behind a large truck. You should drive:
questions.answerA: Closer behind the truck than you would if following a passenger vehicle.
questions.answerB: Farther behind the truck than you would if following a passenger vehicle.
questions.answerC: To the right side of the truck and wait to pass.
questions.explanation: It is necessary to follow farther behind a large truck than you would if following a passenger vehicle because trucks have larger blind spots.

questions.question: Check your rearview mirrors:
questions.answerA: Often to see how traffic is moving behind you.
questions.answerB: To see if a vehicle is in your blind spot.
questions.answerC: Only when you are slowing down.
questions.explanation: When driving, do not develop a fixed stare. Frequently check your rearview mirrors so you know the positions of vehicles near you.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You are about to enter a one-way street from the wrong direction.
questions.answerB: U-turns are prohibited.
questions.answerC: You may proceed if the way is clear.
questions.explanation: This sign marks a one-way road, entrance, or exit. If you are facing this sign, traffic is coming toward you. Turn around if you are driving toward this sign.

questions.question: To improve visibility lowered by rain or fog, drivers should use their:
questions.answerA: Low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: High beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Parking lights.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used when driving in rainy or foggy weather. Even if they do little to help you see, low beams will make it easier for others to see you.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Trucks entering.
questions.answerB: Truck exit only.
questions.answerC: Steep downgrade ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that a steep downgrade is ahead on the road. Drivers should check their brakes.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Side road.
questions.answerB: Merge.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is an intersection with a side road ahead.

questions.question: When may you legally drive around or under a railroad crossing gate?
questions.answerA: Never.
questions.answerB: When you can see clearly in both directions.
questions.answerC: When the warning lights are not flashing.
questions.explanation: Do not go around or under any lowered gate at a railroad crossing. Once the gate is raised, do not proceed across the tracks until you can see clearly in both directions and are sure there are no trains coming.

questions.question: You must yield the right-of-way to an emergency vehicle that is using its siren and flashing lights by:
questions.answerA: Driving as closely to the right edge of the road as possible and stopping.
questions.answerB: Moving into the right lane and driving slowly until it has passed.
questions.answerC: Stopping immediately, even if you are within an intersection.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to any emergency vehicle that is using its siren and flashing lights. Do this by driving to the right edge of the road and stopping, taking care not to stop in an intersection. You may move again after the emergency vehicle has passed.

questions.question: If you are feeling fatigued while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to reach your destination more quickly.
questions.answerB: Increase the volume of your radio.
questions.answerC: Find a safe parking area to take a short nap.
questions.explanation: When driving, watch for warning signs of fatigue. You are too tired to drive safely if you are struggling to keep your eyes open, drifting from your lane, or turning up the radio and rolling down your windows to keep yourself awake. If you notice these signs, it is a good idea to find a safe place to park so you can refresh yourself with a short nap.

questions.question: A broken yellow line between two lanes of traffic means:
questions.answerA: Both lanes of traffic are going in the same direction.
questions.answerB: Passing is permitted when it's safe.
questions.answerC: Passing is not permitted.
questions.explanation: Dashed yellow lines separate single lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions. Passing is allowed when there is no oncoming traffic in the passing lane.

questions.question: Use your headlights on rainy, snowy, or foggy days:
questions.answerA: To keep your engine warm.
questions.answerB: So others can see your vehicle.
questions.answerC: To warn others of bad weather conditions.
questions.explanation: On rainy, snowy, or foggy days, it may be difficult for other drivers to see your vehicle. Under these conditions, headlights make your vehicle easier to see. If the weather requires you to turn on your windshield wipers, you must also turn on your low beam headlights.

questions.question: A large truck is ahead of you and is turning right onto a street with two lanes in each direction. The truck:
questions.answerA: May complete its turn in either of the two lanes.
questions.answerB: May have to swing wide to complete the right turn.
questions.answerC: Must stay in the right lane at all times while turning.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle makes a turn, the rear wheels follow a shorter path than the front wheels. The longer the vehicle, the bigger the difference between the paths of the front and rear wheels. Therefore, long trucks often have to swing wide to complete a right turn.

questions.question: When entering the interstate on a short entrance ramp where there is no acceleration lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Immediately enter the far-right traffic lane on the interstate and speed up to match the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: Use the shoulder of the main road to get up to the speed of traffic.
questions.answerC: Speed up and enter the interstate only after you have identified a gap in traffic.
questions.explanation: When entering the interstate on a short entrance ramp where there is no acceleration lane, speed up only after you have identified a gap in traffic. In general, you should be stopped while waiting for a gap to appear.

questions.question: At dawn or dusk and in rain or snow, it can be hard to see and be seen. A good way to let other drivers know you are there is to turn:
questions.answerA: Up the instrumental panel lights.
questions.answerB: On your parking lights.
questions.answerC: On your headlights.
questions.explanation: You must use your headlights at any time when conditions prevent you from seeing other vehicles and when it may be difficult for other drivers to see you. Always use your low beam headlights if weather conditions require you to use your windshield wipers.

questions.question: If you parallel park facing downward on a hill:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels sharply toward the side of the road.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels away from the side of the road.
questions.answerC: Keep your wheels straight.
questions.explanation: When parking downhill, turn your front wheels toward the curb or edge of the road. When parking uphill on a road without a curb, turn your wheels toward the edge of the road. When parking uphill on a road with a curb, you must turn your front wheels away from the curb.

questions.question: As your speed increases, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Turn on your headlights.
questions.answerB: Look well ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Change lanes frequently.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's stopping distance increases as your speed increases. When driving at high speeds, it is important to look well ahead of your vehicle to allow yourself space to safely react to hazardous situations.

questions.question: When entering the interstate, check for a gap in traffic in the nearest lane, adjust your speed to match traffic, signal, and:
questions.answerA: Expect traffic to allow you to proceed into the lane, since you have the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Merge carefully into the gap.
questions.answerC: Wait for the lane to clear before merging.
questions.explanation: Before merging into interstate traffic, you should identify a gap, accelerate to the speed of traffic, and signal. Merge into the gap when it is safe to do so. Be alert to other traffic and do not expect other drivers to clear the lane.

questions.question: Your license can be suspended if you are under 21 and drive with a blood alcohol level of:
questions.answerA: 0.15 percent or more.
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent or more.
questions.answerC: Any amount.
questions.explanation: There is zero tolerance for alcohol use by drivers under age 21. If you are under 21, the detection of any trace of alcohol in your system will result in stiff penalties, including the suspension of your license for two years.

questions.question: If a child is about to run into the street, you should:
questions.answerA: Start to prepare to slow down.
questions.answerB: Flash your headlights.
questions.answerC: Sound a sharp blast of your horn.
questions.explanation: If there is danger, you may need to sound a sharp blast on your horn. Do this when a child or any other pedestrian is about to enter into the street in front of your moving vehicle.

questions.question: Sudden wind gusts on highways:
questions.answerA: Generally affect only the movement of large vehicles.
questions.answerB: Only cause visibility problems.
questions.answerC: Can cause problems for all vehicles.
questions.explanation: While it can create special problems for large vehicles, strong wind can cause problems for all drivers. Wind can lower visibility by blowing dirt and dust into the roadway, but it can sometimes also physically move a vehicle.

questions.question: You are involved in a minor collision at an intersection. There are no injuries and there is very little vehicle damage. You should:
questions.answerA: Leave your vehicle in the traffic lane until law enforcement arrives.
questions.answerB: Move your vehicle out of the traffic lane, if possible.
questions.answerC: Not move your vehicle for any reason.
questions.explanation: After a collision, if no one has been injured or killed and you can safely do so, you should move your vehicle out of the traffic lane.

questions.question: When approaching a person who is crossing the street while using a white cane or guide dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop until the person is well away from your path of travel.
questions.answerB: Honk your horn as you proceed past them.
questions.answerC: Carefully drive around them.
questions.explanation: When approaching a pedestrian who is using a white cane or guide dog while crossing the street, you must stop until the person is well away from your path of travel. Always yield the right-of-way to blind pedestrians.

questions.question: If you have a sudden tire blowout:
questions.answerA: Use the brakes lightly.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes firmly.
questions.explanation: If a tire suddenly goes flat while you are driving, hold the steering wheel tightly and keep the vehicle moving straight. Slow down gradually by taking your foot off the gas pedal and using the brakes lightly.

questions.question: A reflective orange triangle on the back of a vehicle indicates that:
questions.answerA: It is a slow-moving vehicle.
questions.answerB: It is an ambulance.
questions.answerC: It is a school bus.
questions.explanation: A reflective orange triangle on the rear of a vehicle means the vehicle often moves at speeds of 25 mph or slower. You may see this decal on construction equipment, farm vehicles, and horse-drawn wagons or carriages.

questions.question: If you approach a traffic light with a red signal and a police officer directs you to go through the intersection without stopping, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop until the light turns green.
questions.answerB: Go through the intersection without stopping.
questions.answerC: Come to a complete stop before proceeding.
questions.explanation: Instructions given by police officers directing traffic always override posted traffic signals and signs. Follow the officer's instructions.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow down or stop.
questions.answerB: Stop if necessary.
questions.answerC: You must come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: An octagonal sign always means stop. When approaching a stop sign, you must come to a complete stop at the marked stop line and proceed only when it is safe to do so. If there is no stop line, stop before the crosswalk. If there is no crosswalk, stop before the intersection at a point from which you can see oncoming traffic.

questions.question: You must yield to a pedestrian using a white cane or guide dog:
questions.answerA: Only when the guide dog is leading the person across the street.
questions.answerB: At all times.
questions.answerC: Only if a crossing guard is present.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians who use guide dogs or white canes (with or without a red tip) must be given the right-of-way at all times.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: Rely on the rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move.
questions.answerC: Rely on the left side mirror.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, glance over your shoulder to check for traffic in your blind spot. You may need to look several times before changing lanes. You must keep track of what traffic is doing in front of you as well as what traffic is doing in the lane next to you.

questions.question: When driving in fog, it is best to drive with:
questions.answerA: High beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: Use your low beam headlights when driving in fog, rain, or snow. High beam lights can reflect off the weather conditions, lowering visibility even more.

questions.question: You are driving on the freeway. The vehicle in front of you is a large truck. You should drive:
questions.answerA: Closely behind the truck in bad weather because the driver can see farther ahead than you can.
questions.answerB: Farther behind the truck than you would when following a passenger vehicle.
questions.answerC: No more than one car length behind the truck so the driver can see you.
questions.explanation: When you follow so closely behind a truck that you cannot see the truck driver’s side view mirrors, the trucker cannot see you and has no way of knowing you are there. Tailgating a truck, or any vehicle, is dangerous because you take away your own cushion of safety if the vehicle in front of you stops quickly.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about roadwork zones?
questions.answerA: Fines are the same for violations committed in work zones as they are under normal traffic conditions.
questions.answerB: You must "Slow for the Cone Zone."
questions.answerC: Slow down only if you think workers are present.
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed and be prepared to slow down or stop for highway equipment. Driving carefully through work zones improves safety for drivers, pedestrians, bicyclists, and road workers.

questions.question: If a road is slippery, maintain a following distance that is:
questions.answerA: No different than normal.
questions.answerB: Farther from the car ahead than normal.
questions.answerC: Closer to the car ahead than normal.
questions.explanation: You need a longer distance to stop your vehicle on a slippery road than you do on a dry road. Maintain an increased following distance when driving on slippery roads.

questions.question: In rainy weather, you should be most careful when turning or stopping:
