questions.answerA: After it has been raining all day.
questions.answerB: One half hour after it stops raining.
questions.answerC: During the first half hour of rain.
questions.explanation: You should be extra careful when turning and stopping during the first half hour of rain. At this point, the oil from cars has not yet washed off the pavement and could be forming a slippery mixture with the rain.

questions.question: At an intersection with a yield sign, you:
questions.answerA: Must yield the right-of-way to cross traffic that is close enough to cause conflict.
questions.answerB: Must yield to vehicles only on your right.
questions.answerC: Should slow down but never stop.
questions.explanation: When approaching a yield sign, drivers must give the right-of-way to traffic already in the lanes that they intend to enter or cross. Drivers should be prepared to stop when approaching a yield sign but may continue without stopping if there is no conflicting traffic.

questions.question: If you plan to pass another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Not assume the other driver will make space for you to return to your lane.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver will let you pass if you use your turn signal.
questions.answerC: Assume the other driver will maintain a constant speed.
questions.explanation: Even when you signal, you should not assume that the space you want to occupy is free or that other drivers will give you the right-of-way.

questions.question: "No passing zone" signs tell drivers:
questions.answerA: To speed up slightly.
questions.answerB: That it is not safe to pass.
questions.answerC: To maintain a steady speed.
questions.explanation: If you come across a "No passing zone" sign, it is not legal to pass in the indicated area. You are likely driving in an area with restricted visibility where it would be unsafe to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: If you miss your exit on the freeway, you should not:
questions.answerA: Continue on the freeway and find an alternate route to your destination.
questions.answerB: Proceed to the next exit, leave the freeway, and return to your proper exit.
questions.answerC: Back up on the road or shoulder.
questions.explanation: If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up in the travel lane or on the shoulder. Continue to drive to the next exit or crossroad. Drivers do not expect a vehicle to be backing toward them on the roadway and doing so will likely cause a collision.

questions.question: You may be able to identify an aggressive driver by:
questions.answerA: Their erratic and improper lane changes.
questions.answerB: The number of passengers in their car.
questions.answerC: Their tendency to drive slowly.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should remain aware of the actions of surrounding drivers. If you notice an aggressive driver nearby making erratic or improper lane changes, you should not challenge them. The safest way to handle an aggressive driver is to get out of their way.

questions.question: You are driving behind a motorcycle and want to pass. You must:
questions.answerA: Stay in the right lane as much as possible because the motorcycle is small and doesn't use all of the lane.
questions.answerB: Blow your horn to make the motorcycle move onto the shoulder so that you can pass.
questions.answerC: Have your vehicle entirely in the left lane before and during the pass.
questions.explanation: When passing a motorcycle, allow a full lane to the motorcycle. Never crowd into the same lane as the motorcycle. Returning to the original lane too soon can force a rider to swerve to the right and into traffic or off the road.

questions.question: You enter a designated turn lane to make a left turn at an upcoming intersection. There is oncoming traffic. You should:
questions.answerA: Move to the left of the center lane.
questions.answerB: Signal before you arrive at the intersection.
questions.answerC: Turn your front wheels to the left to be prepared to turn.
questions.explanation: When making a left turn, you should always begin signaling about 100 feet before the turn. You should keep your front wheels aiming straight ahead until it is safe to start your turn. This ensures that you will not be pushed into oncoming traffic if another vehicle hits you from behind.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerB: Steep grade ahead.
questions.answerC: Winding road.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that there is a steep hill ahead. Slow down and be ready to shift to a lower gear to control your speed and protect your brakes from damage.

questions.question: If there is a deep puddle on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerA: Maintain the posted speed to make it through the water.
questions.answerB: Avoid the puddle if possible.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral as you drive through the water.
questions.explanation: To prevent skidding on slippery surfaces, avoid especially slippery areas, such as ice patches, wet leaves, oil, or deep puddles. The safest surface for driving is a dry, solid surface.

questions.question: To see vehicles in your blind spots, you should check:
questions.answerA: The inside rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: The outside rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Over your shoulders.
questions.explanation: By definition, blind spots are areas that cannot be seen using your mirrors. To check your blind spots, you should look over your shoulders.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: Driving too slowly is not an unsafe practice.
questions.answerB: Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous.
questions.answerC: The speed at which you drive a vehicle does not affect safety.
questions.explanation: Driving too slowly can be dangerous because it may cause drivers behind you to become frustrated and make dangerous moves to pass you. It is safest to drive with the flow of traffic, within the legal speed limit.

questions.question: You should not use your horn:
questions.answerA: When visibility ahead is limited.
questions.answerB: If you might hit another vehicle.
questions.answerC: Near blind pedestrians.
questions.explanation: When driving near a blind pedestrian, using your horn may be dangerous. Yield to the pedestrian and proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: A driver should:
questions.answerA: Stare directly in front of their car.
questions.answerB: Only focus on the middle of the road.
questions.answerC: Watch beside, ahead, and to the rear of their car.
questions.explanation: A driver should watch beside, ahead, and to the rear of their car. To be a good driver, you must know what is happening all around your vehicle.

questions.question: If you are driving near a large commercial vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Follow the large vehicle closely to reduce wind drag on your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Avoid driving beside it for long stretches of time.
questions.answerC: Drive on its right side when on curves and hills.
questions.explanation: Because large commercial vehicles have large blind spots on each side, you should avoid driving beside them for long periods of time.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked vehicles, you should:
questions.answerA: Be prepared for a person or vehicle to unexpectedly enter your lane.
questions.answerB: Expect all other drivers and pedestrians to respect your right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Drive closely to the parked vehicles to allow more room for moving traffic.
questions.explanation: Keep a space between your vehicle and parked vehicles. A person may step out of a parked vehicle or out from between the parked vehicles without looking. A driver may begin moving their vehicle before realizing you are there.

questions.question: When you see an emergency vehicle approaching while using its flashing lights, you must:
questions.answerA: Maintain your speed and stay in your lane until the vehicle has passed.
questions.answerB: Move into the right lane and drive slowly until the vehicle has passed.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the curb or edge of the road and stop until the vehicle has passed.
questions.explanation: If you see an emergency vehicle approaching while using its flashing lights, pull over to the right edge of the road and stop. Position yourself parallel to the curb. On one-way streets, drive toward the road edge nearest you.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.answerA: Use your left foot to brake.
questions.answerB: Use your right foot for both braking and accelerating your vehicle.
questions.answerC: You should always brake abruptly to ensure stopping.
questions.explanation: Use your right foot for both braking and accelerating. You should apply the brakes gently with increasing pressure so that your vehicle stops gradually and smoothly.

questions.question: Drivers should look ____ ahead of their vehicle when driving.
questions.answerA: Four seconds
questions.answerB: Seven seconds
questions.answerC: 10 seconds
questions.explanation: To avoid the need for last-minute braking or turning, look down the road at least 10 seconds ahead of your vehicle. By looking ahead and being ready to stop or change lanes if needed, you can drive more safely, save on fuel, and help keep traffic moving at a steady pace.

questions.question: When approaching a stopped school bus that has its stop signal arm extended and its lights flashing, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop and wait to proceed.
questions.answerB: Honk their horn before passing the bus on its left.
questions.answerC: Continue driving when they think most kids are done exiting the bus.
questions.explanation: When you are approaching a school bus that is stopped with its stop arm extended and lights flashing, come to a complete stop. Remain stopped until the stop signal is retracted and the flashing lights are turned off.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Road construction/maintenance area.
questions.answerB: Side road.
questions.answerC: Railroad ahead.
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs are used to warn of actual or possible hazards. The color orange is used for warning signs usually found in construction or maintenance areas.

questions.question: It is very foggy. You should slow down and:
questions.answerA: Turn on your emergency flashers.
questions.answerB: Turn your lights to their high beam setting.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights to their low beam setting.
questions.explanation: Use your low beams when driving in fog, snow, rain, or mist. Light from high beams will reflect off of precipitation, causing a glare and making it even more difficult to see. Some vehicles are equipped with fog lights that should be used in addition to low beam headlights.

questions.question: What is a crosswalk?
questions.answerA: Another name for a four-way intersection.
questions.answerB: An area designated for road construction workers.
questions.answerC: The area where pedestrians may cross the roadway.
questions.explanation: Pedestrian crosswalks are often shown by white, solid lines to emphasize pedestrian crossing points. Crosswalks may have additional lines between the white, solid lines or in place of the parallel lines. However, crosswalks may also be unmarked.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No U-turn.
questions.answerB: No left turn.
questions.answerC: No right turn.
questions.explanation: Where this sign is posted, it is prohibited to make a right turn. It would be unsafe and unlawful to make a right turn at an intersection with this sign.

questions.question: When driving on the highway, consistently looking far ahead of your vehicle:
questions.answerA: Helps you keep up with traffic.
questions.answerB: Reduces the need for last-minute braking or turning.
questions.answerC: Allows you to spot upcoming police officers.
questions.explanation: To avoid the need for last-minute braking or turning, consistently watch the road far ahead of your vehicle. By looking ahead and being ready to stop or change lanes if needed, you can drive more safely, save fuel, and help keep traffic moving at a steady pace.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you:
questions.answerA: Are approaching a railroad crossing and should prepare to stop.
questions.answerB: Will always stop at the upcoming railroad crossing.
questions.answerC: Should stop and wait for a signal before crossing the railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you are approaching a railroad crossing. You must look, listen, slow down, and prepare to stop. Wait for any trains to pass before you proceed.

questions.question: You should not make sudden stops in front of large trucks and buses because:
questions.answerA: Small vehicle drivers cannot adequately see large trucks and buses in their rearview mirrors.
questions.answerB: Large trucks and buses, due to their size and weight, require longer distances to stop than smaller passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Large trucks and buses travel at a higher speeds than small vehicles.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles require longer distances to stop and accelerate than smaller vehicles do. Making a sudden stop in front of a large vehicle is dangerous because the other driver may not be able to stop in time to avoid a collision.

questions.question: To see objects in their blind spot when changing lanes, drivers should check:
questions.answerA: Only the left outside mirror.
questions.answerB: Over their left or right shoulder.
questions.answerC: Only the inside rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's blind spots are the areas that you cannot see in your mirrors. Look over the appropriate shoulder to check your blind spot when changing lanes.

questions.question: This yellow sign means:
questions.answerA: One lane ahead.
questions.answerB: Merging traffic ahead.
questions.answerC: Lane ends ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of the possible presence of merging traffic.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp right turn ahead.
questions.answerB: A road joins from the right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead turns sharply right then sharply left.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that the road ahead will turn sharply to the right and then sharply to the left.

questions.question: A flashing red traffic light at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: The same thing as a yield sign.
questions.answerB: The light is about to turn green.
questions.answerC: The same thing as a stop sign.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light at an intersection means drivers are required to come to a complete stop, yield to traffic and pedestrians, and proceed when the way is clear. The same is true at a stop sign.

questions.question: If you park facing uphill where there is no curb, set the parking brake and:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels toward the edge of the road.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels away from the edge of the road.
questions.answerC: Keep your wheels facing straight.
questions.explanation: When parking uphill on a road that does not have a curb, your front wheels should be turned to the right (toward the edge of the road). This will ensure that the vehicle will roll off of the road if the brakes fail.

questions.question: When driving in fog, rain, or snow, use:
questions.answerA: Low beams.
questions.answerB: High beams.
questions.answerC: Fog lights only.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used in fog, rain, and snow. The light from high beams will reflect back to the driver under these weather conditions, causing a glare that will make it difficult to see ahead.

questions.question: This sign is a:
questions.answerA: Service sign.
questions.answerB: Regulatory sign.
questions.answerC: Warning sign.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. There may be an upcoming change in traffic direction, a steep downgrade, or another potentially hazardous situation that requires action on the part of the driver.

questions.question: As the percentage of alcohol (BAC) in your blood increases, you become:
questions.answerA: More intoxicated.
questions.answerB: More sober.
questions.answerC: More coordinated.
questions.explanation: Blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is a measure of the percentage of alcohol in a person's blood. The higher the BAC, the more impaired a person is.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for bicycles.
questions.answerB: Bicycles not allowed.
questions.answerC: Bicycle repair shop ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. Warning signs may alert drivers to areas where animals, people, and vehicles are likely to cross traffic.

questions.question: When merging onto the freeway, you should be driving:
questions.answerA: At or near the speed of the freeway traffic.
questions.answerB: At the legal speed limit.
questions.answerC: More slowly than the freeway traffic.
questions.explanation: You should enter a freeway at or near the speed of traffic, unless the speed of traffic exceeds the legal speed limit.

questions.question: If the roadway is wet or icy, you should:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: Drive at the posted speed.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.explanation: Because your tires will not grip the road under wet, snowy, or icy conditions as well as they will under dry conditions, you should slow down if the roadway is wet or icy.

questions.question: A broken yellow centerline means that:
questions.answerA: Passing is not permitted.
questions.answerB: Passing on the right is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.answerC: Passing on the left is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow centerline means that a driver may cross the centerline to pass another vehicle on the left as long as there is no oncoming traffic. Drivers should never cross a solid yellow centerline in order to pass.

questions.question: This white sign means:
questions.answerA: The railroad crossing is controlled. Continue at your regular speed.
questions.answerB: Look, listen, and prepare to stop at the crossing if necessary.
questions.answerC: Stop at the railroad tracks and wait for a signal before crossing.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing, you must look, listen, slow down, and prepare to stop. Let any trains pass before you proceed.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: You must turn right.
questions.answerB: No right turns permitted.
questions.answerC: Right turns permitted on a red light.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits right turns. It is illegal to turn right at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: If a child is riding a bicycle near your vehicle:
questions.answerA: Beep your horn.
questions.answerB: Expect the child to be in total control of the bicycle.
questions.answerC: Expect the unexpected.
questions.explanation: Children on bicycles are sometimes unpredictable. Young bicyclists are especially likely to make surprising changes in direction. Remember that children and bicycles are both small in stature and may become difficult to see.

questions.question: You are driving on a one-way street. You may only turn left onto another one-way street if:
questions.answerA: You increase your speed before the turn.
questions.answerB: Traffic on the street moves to the right.
questions.answerC: Traffic on the street moves to the left.
questions.explanation: You may turn left onto a one-way street that moves to the left if there is no sign prohibiting the turn. You may not turn left onto a one-way street where traffic moves to the right.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: School crossing.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerC: Jogging trail.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates the presence of a crosswalk, regardless of if it is marked on the pavement or not. Upon seeing this sign, you should be alert and allow any pedestrians to cross the road safely.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about driving and taking medications?
questions.answerA: Most cold medications can make a person drowsy.
questions.answerB: Over-the-counter medications cannot impair driving ability if taken in the recommended dosages.
questions.answerC: Medications are safe to take at any time, if prescribed by a doctor.
questions.explanation: Remember that all medications, prescription or over-the-counter, are potentially dangerous and could impair your driving. Over-the-counter medicines that you take for colds and allergies can make you drowsy and affect your driving ability. It is your responsibility to know how your medication affects your ability to drive.

questions.question: A broken yellow line beside a solid yellow line indicates that:
questions.answerA: Passing is permitted from the lane next to the solid yellow line.
questions.answerB: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerC: Passing is permitted from the lane next to the broken yellow line.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow line alongside a solid yellow line means that traffic in the lane next to the broken line may cross the line to pass, while traffic in the lane next to the solid line may not.

questions.question: What is the purpose of rumble strips?
questions.answerA: They alert drivers to potential tire problems.
questions.answerB: They test a vehicle's shock absorbers.
questions.answerC: Through vibration and sound, they alert inattentive drivers to the fact that their vehicles have left the travel lane.
questions.explanation: Rumble strips create noise and vibrations to warn drowsy or inattentive drivers that they are straying off of the road or are approaching a stop sign or signal.

questions.question: If you want to pass a pedestrian who is walking along the roadway and an oncoming vehicle is approaching, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and let the oncoming vehicle pass before you pass the pedestrian.
questions.answerB: Keep driving at a steady speed. The oncoming vehicle must stop for you.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn to get the pedestrian to move over.
questions.explanation: If possible, try to only deal with one roadway hazard at a time. If you want to pass a pedestrian but an oncoming vehicle is approaching, slow down and let the vehicle pass. You may then pass the pedestrian if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Alcohol is:
questions.answerA: A stimulant.
questions.answerB: An antihistamine.
questions.answerC: A depressant.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant that dulls your judgment and makes your reflexes unreliable.

questions.question: If your vehicle has a mechanical problem:
questions.answerA: Signal and pull into the slow lane.
questions.answerB: Stop in your lane and put on your hazard lights.
questions.answerC: Put on your hazard lights and pull off the road.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on a highway, make sure other drivers can see it. Get your vehicle off the road and away from traffic if at all possible and turn on your emergency flashers to show that you are having trouble.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No right turn.
questions.answerB: Stop sign ahead.
questions.answerC: Divided highway.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that turns in the direction of the arrow (in this case, to the right) are prohibited.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Traffic signal ahead.
questions.answerB: Stop.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of of an approaching traffic signal.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: Merge.
questions.answerC: Upcoming change in direction.
questions.explanation: An eight-sided red sign means "stop."

questions.question: A sign with this shape means:
questions.answerA: Railroad crossing.
questions.answerB: Warning.
questions.answerC: Signal ahead.
questions.explanation: A diamond-shaped yellow sign warns of possible danger ahead. Orange signs, which are mostly diamond-shaped, are used to warn of possible dangers in or near work areas.

questions.question: When parallel parking, you should park within ____ of the curb.
questions.answerA: Three feet
questions.answerB: Two feet
questions.answerC: One foot
questions.explanation: When parallel parking, your wheels should be parallel to and within one foot of the curb. Only park where you will not be disruptive to traffic and where drivers can clearly see your vehicle from both directions.

questions.question: A vehicle suddenly cuts in front of you, creating a hazard. What should you do first?
questions.answerA: Honk and step on the brake firmly.
questions.answerB: Take your foot off the gas pedal.
questions.answerC: Swerve into the lane next to you.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle merges in front of you too closely, take your foot off of the accelerator. This will create space between you and the vehicle ahead without requiring you to slam on your brakes or swerve into another lane.

questions.question: This sign indicates that the road ahead:
questions.answerA: Turns sharply right, then left.
questions.answerB: Curves right, then left.
questions.answerC: Curves right.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of a reverse curve in which the road curves to the right, then to the left.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about blind spots is true?
questions.answerA: Blind spots are eliminated if you have one outside mirror.
questions.answerB: Large trucks have bigger blind spots than most passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Blind spots can be checked by looking in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Even if a vehicle is properly equipped with rearview and outside mirrors, it still has blind spots that cannot be seen in the mirrors. Large trucks have much larger blind spots than most passenger vehicles.

questions.question: Excessive speed:
questions.answerA: Does not increase the chance of a crash.
questions.answerB: Increases your ability to react to a hazard.
questions.answerC: Often leads to high-risk decision-making.
questions.explanation: Excessive speed is one of the most common contributing factors to vehicle crashes. Excessive speed does not save time and often leads to high-risk decision-making.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should never:
questions.answerA: Cross the centerline in an intersection.
questions.answerB: Check your blind spots by looking over your left or right shoulder.
questions.answerC: Check for other drivers moving into the same lane.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check for drivers trying to pass you who may be trying to enter the same lane as you. Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. You should never attempt to pass or otherwise change lanes in an intersection.

questions.question: When traveling at high speeds, drivers should signal ____ before making a turn.
questions.answerA: Two seconds
questions.answerB: Four to five seconds
questions.answerC: 10 seconds
questions.explanation: Drivers must use their turn signals before changing lanes or making a turn. Drivers traveling at high speeds should signal four to five seconds before moving to the left or right.

questions.question: If your car becomes disabled while on the highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop in the right lane.
questions.answerB: Park with all four wheels off the traveled highway, if possible.
questions.answerC: Stop where you are.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle becomes disabled, you must (if possible) park with all four wheels off of the main-traveled portion of the road.

questions.question: From top to bottom, the following is the proper order for traffic lights:
questions.answerA: Red, yellow, green.
questions.answerB: Red, green, yellow.
questions.answerC: Green, red, yellow.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers about the presence of traffic signals at an intersection ahead.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with airbags:
questions.answerA: Seat belts should still be worn.
questions.answerB: Seat belts do not need to be worn.
questions.answerC: Seat belts should be worn behind the back.
questions.explanation: Airbags are important safety devices that provide protection in crashes. For best protection, a vehicle's lap and shoulder belts should be used in combination with airbags.

questions.question: Which of the following factors affect an individual's absorption of alcohol?
questions.answerA: Weight
questions.answerB: Height
questions.answerC: Intelligence
questions.explanation: Factors affecting a person's absorption of alcohol include the person's weight, their biological sex, the amount of food in their digestive tract, and the number of alcoholic beverages they have consumed. The only thing to do to remove alcohol from a person's system is to wait.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: There is a 35 mph speed zone after the curve ahead.
questions.answerB: Drive no slower than 35 mph around the upcoming curve.
questions.answerC: Approach the upcoming curve at a speed of 35 mph or slower.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. These signs may be accompanied by speed advisory plaques that indicate the speed with which you should proceed.

questions.question: Drivers must use their parking brake:
questions.answerA: Only when parked on an incline.
questions.answerB: Only when parked in a parking lot.
questions.answerC: Every time they park.
questions.explanation: Always set your parking brake when you park. Leave the vehicle in gear if it has a manual transmission or in “Park” if it has an automatic transmission.

questions.question: When adjusting your rearview mirror, you should be able to clearly see:
questions.answerA: The entire rear window.
questions.answerB: The passengers in the backseat.
questions.answerC: Your own reflection.
questions.explanation: Adjust your inside rearview mirror so you can see the entire rear window from the driver's seat. You should have to move only your eyes, not your head, when using this mirror.

questions.question: To improve visibility lowered by rain or fog, drivers should use their:
questions.answerA: Low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: High beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Parking lights.
questions.explanation: Use low beam headlights when driving in rain, snow, sleet, or fog. High beam headlights in adverse weather conditions lower visibility by reflecting off the precipitation and back into the driver's eyes.

questions.question: If you are driving and you see animals standing near the roadway:
questions.answerA: Speed up to scare them away.
questions.answerB: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Quickly swerve into the next lane.
questions.explanation: Slow down and proceed with caution if you see animals that are standing near the roadway. They may unexpectedly bolt or change direction at the last moment. Some animals travel in packs, so there may be more animals just out of sight that are also near the road.

questions.question: In traffic moving at 50 to 55 mph, you are least likely to have an accident if you:
questions.answerA: Drive a few miles per hour faster than most other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Stay within that speed range.
questions.answerC: Drive a few miles per hour slower than most other vehicles.
questions.explanation: You should adjust your speed to travel smoothly with the other traffic on a roadway (provided that the other traffic is driving within the posted speed limits). Remember that vehicles moving in the same direction at the same speed cannot hit each other. Crashes involving multiple vehicles often happen when some vehicles are traveling at different speeds than others.

questions.question: Broken yellow lines are used on streets and highways to:
questions.answerA: Indicate no passing zones.
questions.answerB: Separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction.
questions.answerC: Separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Dashed lines on the pavement indicate that passing is permitted when safe.

questions.question: This is the shape and color of a ____ sign.
questions.answerA: Stop
questions.answerB: Wrong way
questions.answerC: Yield
questions.explanation: Downward-facing triangular signs mean drivers must yield. When approaching a yield sign, slow down to a speed that is reasonable for existing conditions and stop if necessary. If you must stop, do so at a marked stop line, if it exists.

questions.question: A school bus is stopped ahead of you in your lane with its red lights flashing. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop and proceed when you think all of the children have exited the bus.
questions.answerB: Slow to 25 mph and pass cautiously.
questions.answerC: Stop for as long as the red lights are flashing.
questions.explanation: When a stopped school bus is using its flashing red lights, approaching drivers must stop and remain stopped until the lights stop flashing. If the school bus is on the opposite side of a divided highway, drivers do not need to stop.

questions.question: At a school crossing sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop, whether there is a stop sign or not.
questions.answerB: Watch for children and be ready to stop.
questions.answerC: Always sound your horn when you see children.
questions.explanation: Pentagonal signs mean you are approaching a school zone and/or school crossing. When you see these signs, be alert and prepare to stop.

questions.question: What does a traffic signal with a yellow left arrow indicate?
questions.answerA: Drivers should prepare to yield to oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: The protected left turn is about to end.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: When a protected turn arrow changes from green to yellow, drivers must prepare to yield to oncoming traffic. A yellow arrow indicates that the protected left turn is ending.

questions.question: Temporary signs used in construction and maintenance work areas:
questions.answerA: Have a red background with green writing.
questions.answerB: Have an orange background with black writing.
questions.answerC: Have a yellow background with blue writing.
questions.explanation: All temporary signs in work zones have orange backgrounds with black writing and/or symbols.

questions.question: Accumulating ____ on your license within a 12-month period will result in the suspension of your license.
questions.answerA: 15 points
questions.answerB: 10 points
questions.answerC: Eight points
questions.explanation: Certain offenses committed while driving will count against a driver in South Dakota's system of suspending driver licenses. If a driver accrues 15 points or more within a 12-month period, their license will be suspended. Lengths of suspension vary based on how many offenses the driver has committed.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Merge.
questions.answerB: Winding road ahead.
questions.answerC: Reserved parking for persons with disabilities.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that two lanes of traffic going the same direction will soon merge into one lane.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow-moving vehicle.
questions.answerB: Road construction/maintenance area.
questions.answerC: Traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign is displayed on slow-moving vehicles.

questions.question: You must show proof of insurance to law enforcement:
questions.answerA: Only if you are involved in a collision.
questions.answerB: If you are involved in a collision or stopped for a citation.
questions.answerC: Only if you are stopped and cited.
questions.explanation: You must have evidence of financial responsibility, such as proof of insurance, with you whenever you drive. You must always show proof of insurance and your license to an officer upon request after a traffic stop or collision.

questions.question: You should drive on the shoulder to pass a car:
questions.answerA: If the vehicle ahead of you is turning left.
questions.answerB: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerC: If the shoulder is wide enough.
questions.explanation: Passing on the right is permissible only if it is possible to do so without driving off the roadway. Never pass another vehicle on the shoulder because the other driver will not expect you to be there and may pull off the road.

questions.question: How should drivers apply the gas pedal?
questions.answerA: Slowly and smoothly
questions.answerB: As quickly as possible
questions.answerC: By lightly tapping
questions.explanation: The acceleration pedal should be pressed slowly and smoothly. Depressing the gas pedal too quickly can cause your wheels to overspin, making it difficult to control your vehicle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerB: Side road.
questions.answerC: Railroad ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a pedestrian crosswalk.

questions.question: Signs with orange backgrounds are:
questions.answerA: General warning signs.
questions.answerB: Construction and maintenance warning signs.
questions.answerC: Regulatory signs.
questions.explanation: The color orange is used only for construction and maintenance warning signs.

questions.question: Changing from one lane to another is best done:
questions.answerA: Quickly and often.
questions.answerB: When a car is in your blind spot.
questions.answerC: Gradually and carefully.
questions.explanation: You should always change lanes gradually and carefully. Only change lanes when necessary. Every lane change increases the possibility of a traffic accident.

questions.question: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Challenge them.
questions.answerB: Get out of their way.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.explanation: Drivers must respect and cooperate with all other road users and conform to specific rules in order to maintain order and to avoid crashes. When encountering an aggressive driver, it is safest to just get out of their way. Always avoid competing with other drivers.

questions.question: When passing on the left of a vehicle, it is safe to move back into the right lane:
questions.answerA: After about three seconds.
questions.answerB: When you can no longer see the vehicle over your right shoulder.
questions.answerC: When you can see the front of the vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on its left, you may move back into the right lane when the headlights of the passed vehicle can be seen in your rearview mirror. Always signal before changing lanes.

questions.question: In which of the following scenarios should your wheels not be pointed straight ahead?
questions.answerA: When waiting to make a left turn at a traffic light.
questions.answerB: When parked on a hill or sloping driveway.
questions.answerC: When parked on the side of a level roadway where there is no curb.
questions.explanation: While waiting to turn left, keep your wheels pointed straight ahead until it is safe to start your turn. If a vehicle hits you from behind, this will prevent you from veering into oncoming traffic. When parked facing either uphill or downhill, turn the wheels so the vehicle will not roll into traffic if the brakes fail.

questions.question: You are entering a freeway. Check traffic on the freeway by:
questions.answerA: Using your rearview and side mirrors.
questions.answerB: Using your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Using your side mirror and looking over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: When entering any roadway, you must be aware of traffic conditions. Use your side mirror and look over your shoulder to help you see and anticipate traffic when entering a freeway.

questions.question: What should you do when you see this sign?
questions.answerA: Look for a train station ahead.
questions.answerB: Signal before going any further.
questions.answerC: Slow down and yield to trains.
questions.explanation: A round sign means you are approaching a railroad crossing. This sign is posted a few hundred feet in front of the tracks and tells drivers to slow down, look, listen, and prepare to stop.

questions.question: To enter a gap in highway traffic:
questions.answerA: Watch only the vehicles behind the gap.
questions.answerB: Check behind you, then watch the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerC: Speed up and let the other vehicles make way.
questions.explanation: Whenever you want to change lanes or enter traffic, you must be sure that there are no vehicles in your way in the lane you want to enter. Always check for traffic to the side of and behind your vehicle before you change lanes.

questions.question: It is necessary to use your low beams any time you are:
questions.answerA: On a lighted street.
questions.answerB: On a freeway.
questions.answerC: In fog.
questions.explanation: Use your low beams when driving in fog, snow, rain, or mist. Light from high beams will reflect off of precipitation, causing a glare and making it even more difficult to see. Some vehicles are equipped with fog lights that should be used in addition to low beam headlights.

questions.question: You want to turn left at an upcoming corner. Yield the right-of-way to:
questions.answerA: Oncoming vehicles also turning left.
questions.answerB: All approaching vehicles.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians on the sidewalk waiting for a "Walk" signal.
questions.explanation: When making a left turn, you must yield to pedestrians, bicyclists, or other vehicles moving on their green light.

questions.question: Head restraints should be:
questions.answerA: Adjusted to contact the back of the head.
questions.answerB: Removed from the seats, if possible.
questions.answerC: Anywhere, as they have no effect on either the driver or passengers.
questions.explanation: Head restraints are designed to prevent whiplash if your vehicle is hit from behind. They should be adjusted to contact the back of your head.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Do not enter.
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits drivers from making a U-turn. You cannot turn around to go in the opposite direction at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: When you drive through a construction zone, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop to watch the workers.
questions.answerB: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerC: Pass the construction zone carefully and not “rubberneck."
questions.explanation: To avoid contributing to chronic traffic congestion, you should not "rubberneck." That is, you should not slow down to look at out-of-the-ordinary things.

questions.question: Driving more slowly than surrounding traffic is:
questions.answerA: A good idea if the weather is bad.
questions.answerB: Appropriate if you don’t know the speed limit.
questions.answerC: Often a hazard because other drivers may become frustrated and try to pass you.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than other traffic can be dangerous. Drivers behind you may become impatient and will be tempted to take dangerous risks to pass you.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely to be slippery in cold weather after snow or rain?
questions.answerA: A hilly, open road
questions.answerB: A residential road
questions.answerC: A road in a shaded area
questions.explanation: On cold, wet days, shaded spots on a roadway can become icy. Shaded areas often freeze before, and thaw out after, the rest of a road.

questions.question: When passing, you should move back into the right lane when:
questions.answerA: You are one vehicle length ahead of the passed vehicle.
questions.answerB: You can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: You are 50 feet ahead of the passed vehicle.
questions.explanation: Do not pass unless you have enough space to return to the driving lane. Before you return to the driving lane, be sure you have enough room between yourself and the vehicle you have passed. When you can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror, it is safe to return to the driving lane.

questions.question: There are two traffic lanes moving in your direction. You are driving in the left lane and many vehicles are passing you on the right. If the driver behind you wishes to drive faster, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in your lane so you don't impede the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: Drive onto the left shoulder to let the other vehicles pass.
questions.answerC: Move into the right lane when it is safe.
questions.explanation: To drive quickly, pass, or turn left, use the left lane. Use the right lane when driving more slowly than surrounding traffic, entering the road, or turning right.

questions.question: When you see this black and yellow sign, it means:
questions.answerA: The road to the right is for one-way traffic only.
questions.answerB: There is a detour to the right due to road construction.
questions.answerC: The road ahead changes direction at an extreme angle.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign tells drivers to slow down and prepare for an abrupt change in direction at an extreme angle.

questions.question: If you are being followed too closely on a two-lane road:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed slowly to encourage the tailgater to drive around you.
questions.answerB: Speed up to increase the distance between you and the other car.
questions.answerC: Apply your brakes to slow down, then resume your original speed.
questions.explanation: If you are being followed too closely by another driver, merge into a different lane. If there is no lane available for merging, wait until the road ahead is clear and slowly reduce your speed. This will encourage the tailgater to drive around you.

questions.question: This yellow signs means:
questions.answerA: The road ahead has many curves.
questions.answerB: There is a sharp curve in the road ahead.
questions.answerC: The road ahead may be slippery.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead may be slippery when wet.

questions.question: Where is it safe to pass another vehicle?
questions.answerA: Within an intersection where there are no oncoming vehicles
questions.answerB: Wherever signs and/or pavement markings permit passing
questions.answerC: Within a curve where there are no oncoming vehicles
questions.explanation: Never pass within intersections or at other intersecting points, such as parking lot entrances and alleyways. Any time your view is blocked by a curve or a hill, you should stay in your lane and assume that there is an oncoming vehicle just out of sight. Wherever signs and/or pavement markings permit passing other vehicles, you will have to determine whether or not you have enough space to pass in a safe manner.

questions.question: You should always travel:
questions.answerA: At the speed of vehicles surrounding you.
questions.answerB: At the speed limit.
questions.answerC: At a speed appropriate for road and weather conditions.
questions.explanation: The speed at which you should drive your vehicle depends on road conditions, the weather, and the legal speed limit. You may never drive above the legal speed limit. Decrease your speed when anything makes conditions less than ideal.

questions.question: "No zones" are areas around trucks where cars:
questions.answerA: Disappear into blind spots or are so close that they restrict the truck driver's ability to stop and maneuver safely.
questions.answerB: Have sufficient space to travel behind the truck.
questions.answerC: Have several car lengths between their vehicle and the truck.
questions.explanation: "No zones" are areas around trucks or buses in which cars disappear into the larger vehicle's blind spots. "No zones" can also be defined as areas in which cars are so close to the larger vehicle that they restrict the truck or bus driver’s ability to stop and maneuver safely. A car being in a "No zone" greatly increases the potential for a crash.

questions.question: You are crossing an intersection and an emergency vehicle is approaching while using its siren and flashing lights. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop immediately in the intersection until it passes.
questions.answerB: Pull to the right of the intersection and stop.
questions.answerC: Continue through the intersection, pull to the right, and stop.
questions.explanation: If you are in an intersection when you see an emergency vehicle approaching while using its flashing lights and/or siren, continue through the intersection and then drive to the right and stop. You must yield the right-of-way to any police vehicle, fire engine, ambulance, or other emergency vehicle using a siren or flashing lights.

questions.question: Crosswalks are:
questions.answerA: Always indicated by pavement markings.
questions.answerB: Either indicated by pavement markings or are not marked at all.
questions.answerC: Always unmarked.
questions.explanation: Crosswalks exist whether the lines are marked or unmarked. You must stop behind a crosswalk to allow any pedestrians to cross.

questions.question: Before you change lanes, you should check your mirrors and:
questions.answerA: Never look over your right shoulder.
questions.answerB: Always slow down in your traffic lane.
questions.answerC: Glance over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, it is very important to check behind you. You should look over your shoulder to ensure that you are not getting in the way of vehicles in the lane you want to enter. Before changing lanes, you should also ensure that no drivers are attempting to drive into the same spot from a different lane.

questions.question: When are drivers required to use their headlights?
questions.answerA: One half hour after sunset until one half hour before sunrise
questions.answerB: During the day in clear weather
questions.answerC: When they are tired
questions.explanation: Headlights must be used from one half hour after sunset until one half hour before sunrise. They must also be used at any other time when visibility is less than 200 feet.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for people crossing your path.
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: Work zone ahead.
questions.explanation: This orange warning sign tells drivers that an area of roadwork is upcoming. When traveling through a work zone, stay alert for temporary traffic control devices.

questions.question: Distracted driving is:
questions.answerA: Anything that causes evasive action while driving.
questions.answerB: Anything that takes your attention away from driving.
questions.answerC: Anything that causes you to pay more attention to driving.
questions.explanation: The term “distracted driving” refers to driving while anything takes your eyes, hands, or mind away from the task at hand. Distracted driving is the most common contributing factor to reported traffic collisions. Distractions of any sort cause drivers to miss key visual and audio cues needed to avoid a crash.

questions.question: Allow extra space in front of your vehicle when following a:
questions.answerA: Station wagon.
questions.answerB: Passenger vehicle.
questions.answerC: Motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Allow for extra space when driving behind a motorcycle. Motorcycles can stop more quickly than other vehicles can and you must have adequate room to stop if the motorcyclist brakes or falls off. Also, remember that motorcycles are difficult to see at night because they only have one tail light.

questions.question: While driving on a roadway with a single broken white centerline:
questions.answerA: You must stay within your lane.
questions.answerB: You may cross the centerline to change lanes.
questions.answerC: You may change lanes only from the left lane.
questions.explanation: White lines between lanes indicate that the lanes are traveling in the same direction. Broken white line markings indicate that it is legal to pass another vehicle when safe.

questions.question: This sign shows one type of:
questions.answerA: Right turn.
questions.answerB: Intersection.
questions.answerC: Lane change.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns that your current road ends at an intersection straight ahead. Slow down and prepare to yield or stop before turning right or left.

questions.question: A steady red arrow displayed on a traffic light means:
questions.answerA: Drivers cannot turn in the indicated direction.
questions.answerB: Drivers may turn in the indicated direction after coming to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Drivers may turn in the indicated direction.
questions.explanation: If a traffic signal is displaying a steady red arrow, traffic in the indicated lane may not proceed in the direction shown by the arrow. Drivers must come to a full stop and wait for a green signal to proceed.

questions.question: When turning left from a two-way street onto a one-way street, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn into any lane.
questions.answerB: Turn into first lane.
questions.answerC: Turn into second lane.
questions.explanation: When making any turn, turn from the lane closest to the direction you wish to travel into the first available legal lane. On a turn from a two-way to a one-way street, this means you should turn into the first lane.

questions.question: When should drivers use hand-over-hand steering?
questions.answerA: When turning the wheel during normal driving activity.
questions.answerB: When backing or when momentarily turning on blinkers, the radio, or windshield wipers.
questions.answerC: When turning the wheel at low speeds to make a sharp turn.
questions.explanation: When turning a sharp corner, turn the steering wheel by using the hand-over-hand technique. When you complete the turn, straighten out the steering wheel by hand.

questions.question: When entering an interstate highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop, check for cars, and enter when safe.
questions.answerB: Check for cars and reduce your speed to 25 mph before entering the traffic lane.
questions.answerC: Check for cars, increase your speed to match the flow of traffic, and merge when the way is clear.
questions.explanation: Rather than stopping (as you would when entering other roads), you must use the merging or acceleration lane to speed up and smoothly merge with fast-moving traffic already on the interstate.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: When pavement is wet, reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: The road ahead winds in a series of turns or curves.
questions.answerC: Traffic increases ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that the roadway will be slippery when wet and they should reduce their speed accordingly.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop sign ahead.
questions.answerB: Railroad crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Construction ahead.
questions.explanation: A round sign always indicates that you are approaching a railroad crossing.

questions.question: Highway pavement will be particularly treacherous and most slippery:
questions.answerA: If it has been raining several hours.
questions.answerB: If it has just begun to rain.
questions.answerC: If it has been raining for one to two hours.
questions.explanation: Pavement is particularly treacherous when it first begins to rain. Accumulations of dirt and oil mix with the rainwater, creating a greasy film on the roadway.

questions.question: If you find yourself in a skid:
questions.answerA: Brake lightly.
questions.answerB: Stay off the brakes.
questions.answerC: Brake abruptly.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to skid, do not use the brakes. Braking could make the skid worse.

questions.question: You can drive off the road to pass another vehicle:
questions.answerA: If the vehicle ahead is turning left.
questions.answerB: If there are two or more lanes traveling in your direction.
questions.answerC: Under no circumstances.
questions.explanation: You may never drive off the paved or main-traveled portion of the road and onto the shoulder to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: A pedestrian starts to cross the street after the "Don't Walk" signal begins to flash. The pedestrian is in the middle of the street when your signal light changes to green. You should:
questions.answerA: Proceed if you have the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Proceed if the pedestrian is not in your lane.
questions.answerC: Wait until the pedestrian crosses the street before proceeding.
questions.explanation: At a green light, you must give the right-of-way to any vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian in the intersection. If a pedestrian begins crossing the street after the traffic signal light starts flashing, wait until they have crossed the street before proceeding.

questions.question: When driving at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Always use your high beams.
questions.answerB: Look directly at the headlights of an oncoming vehicle.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: Increase your following distance when it is difficult to see due to darkness. Use headlights to increase visibility, following the rules for proper use of high beams and low beams. Avoid looking directly at the headlights of an oncoming vehicle to avoid being blinded by the glare.

questions.question: Blue traffic signs offer information on:
questions.answerA: Motorist services.
questions.answerB: Construction and maintenance.
questions.answerC: Mileage information, such as distances to specific locations.
questions.explanation: Blue signs on the roadway are service signs. They are used to provide information about motorist services, such as upcoming rest areas, food options, or nearby hospitals.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No turns.
questions.answerB: No outlet.
questions.answerC: No U-turns.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that U-turns are prohibited. You may see a sign like this at an intersection that commonly has oncoming traffic.

questions.question: You have allowed the wheels of your vehicle to run off the edge of the pavement. What should you do first?
questions.answerA: Turn the front wheels slightly to the left to edge the car back onto the pavement.
questions.answerB: Hold the steering wheel firmly, release the gas pedal, and gently apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes and turn the front wheels sharply to the left.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle leaves the roadway, hold the steering wheel firmly, release the gas pedal, and gently apply the brakes. Wait until your speed has reduced, check the traffic, and look for a place to safely return to the roadway by merging back into traffic. Overcompensating by jerking the wheel to return to the roadway can cause you to lose control of your vehicle or may cause your car to go into other lanes of traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No passing zone.
questions.answerB: Slow-moving vehicle.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: A triangular yellow sign with black lettering indicates a no passing zone. It will appear on the left side of a two-way, two-lane roadway at the beginning of an area where prohibitive pavement markings are also used.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No left turn can be made here.
questions.answerB: A left turn can be made only after stopping.
questions.answerC: All traffic must turn right at the next intersection.
questions.explanation: Signs with a red circle and diagonal line over a black symbol indicate that the action represented by the symbol is prohibited. In this case, the sign indicates that left turns are prohibited.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp turn to the right ahead.
questions.answerB: Upcoming sharp left and right turns.
questions.answerC: Winding road ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns the driver that there is an upcoming winding road. Speed should be adjusted appropriately.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Winding road ahead.
questions.answerB: Do not enter.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of a winding road ahead.

questions.question: When driving down a long or steep hill, you should:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors for speeding traffic behind you.
questions.answerB: Assume all traffic is maintaining a consistent speed.
questions.answerC: Hold down your brake pedal to control the speed of surrounding traffic.
questions.explanation: Check your mirrors for quickly approaching vehicles when you are driving down hills or mountains. Vehicles often build up speed while traveling down a steep grade. Be alert to large trucks and buses that may be going too fast.

questions.question: Yellow lines separate:
questions.answerA: Traffic lanes on one-way streets.
questions.answerB: Traffic moving in opposite directions on two-way roads.
questions.answerC: All carpool lanes from regular traffic lanes.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines mark the center of a road used for two-way traffic. A solid yellow centerline indicates that drivers may not cross the line to pass. A broken yellow centerline indicates that drivers may cross the line to pass, but only if passing would not interfere with traffic.

questions.question: Continuous hard braking on ice and snow often:
questions.answerA: Helps you stop faster.
questions.answerB: Locks the front wheels of a vehicle, causing a loss of steering.
questions.answerC: Keeps the brakes from freezing.
questions.explanation: Continuous hard braking on snow and ice can result in the locking of the front brake, causing a loss of steering. To avoid the need for excessive braking, make sure to maintain an appropriate speed for conditions.

questions.question: You should signal continuously while turning because it:
questions.answerA: Is illegal to turn off your signal before completing a turn.
questions.answerB: Lets other drivers know what your intentions are.
questions.answerC: Is always unsafe to turn off a signal before completing a turn.
questions.explanation: You should always signal when turning, changing lanes, slowing down, or stopping so that other drivers, motorcyclists, bicyclists, and pedestrians will know your intentions.

questions.question: Having a driver license is a:
questions.answerA: Requirement.
questions.answerB: Privilege.
questions.answerC: Right.
questions.explanation: It is important to remember that driving is a privilege and that all drivers play a role in ensuring that everyone remains safe on the roadways. If you prove to be abusive of that privilege, the privilege may be revoked.

questions.question: How many alcoholic drinks does it take to affect your driving ability?
questions.answerA: Three
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: One
questions.explanation: It is not advisable to drive after drinking any amount of alcohol. Even a single drink will affect your ability to drive safely.

questions.question: Drivers are required to obey instructions from:
questions.answerA: Security guards patrolling parking lots.
questions.answerB: Other drivers whose vehicles are broken down on the roadway.
questions.answerC: Flaggers (signal persons) at construction sites.
questions.explanation: Drivers must obey special signs or instructions given by flaggers. They are in place to keep drivers and workers safe.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerB: Side road.
questions.answerC: Railroad ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a pedestrian crosswalk.

questions.question: The first thing that alcohol effects is:
questions.answerA: Vision.
questions.answerB: Judgment.
questions.answerC: Balance.
questions.explanation: Alcohol reduces all of the important abilities you need to drive safely. Alcohol goes from your stomach to your blood, then from your blood to all other parts of your body. Alcohol affects the areas of your brain that control judgment and skill.

questions.question: If you have a sudden tire blowout:
questions.answerA: Use the brakes lightly.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes firmly.
questions.explanation: If a tire suddenly goes flat while you are driving, hold the steering wheel tightly and keep the vehicle moving straight. Slow down gradually by taking your foot off the gas pedal and using the brakes lightly.

questions.question: A sign with this shape means:
questions.answerA: No passing zone.
questions.answerB: Right turn permitted on red.
questions.answerC: Yield right-of-way.
questions.explanation: A pennant-shaped sign marks the beginning of a no passing zone.

questions.question: Double solid yellow line markings down the center of a road indicate that passing is:
questions.answerA: Allowed from both directions.
questions.answerB: Allowed only from your direction of travel.
questions.answerC: Not allowed from either direction.
questions.explanation: A double yellow centerline means that it is prohibited for traffic from either direction to cross the centerline to pass.

questions.question: When double solid yellow lines separate lanes of traffic:
questions.answerA: Passing is permitted from the left.
questions.answerB: Passing is permitted from the right.
questions.answerC: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separating lanes of traffic indicate that traffic is moving in opposite directions. Double solid lines indicate that passing is not permitted from either direction.

questions.question: How should drivers apply the gas pedal?
questions.answerA: Slowly and smoothly
questions.answerB: As quickly as possible
questions.answerC: By lightly tapping
questions.explanation: The acceleration pedal should be pressed slowly and smoothly. Depressing the gas pedal too quickly can cause your wheels to overspin, making it difficult to control your vehicle.

questions.question: Make room for cars that are entering the freeway by:
questions.answerA: Slowing down.
questions.answerB: Merging into a different lane.
questions.answerC: Maintaining your speed and position.
questions.explanation: Make room for vehicles that are entering a freeway. If possible, merge into the next lane to create a gap for the incoming vehicles. If you cannot merge, adjust your speed to allow for the vehicles to enter traffic as smoothly and safely as possible.

questions.question: A pentagon-shaped sign is a:
questions.answerA: Stop sign.
questions.answerB: Regulatory sign.
questions.answerC: School zone or school crossing sign.
questions.explanation: A five-sided sign is used to alert drivers to a school zone. Some pentagonal signs specifically indicate crosswalks within school zones where children or other pedestrians may be present.

questions.question: You want to park uphill on a two-way road and there is no curb. Which direction do you turn your front wheels?
questions.answerA: Straight ahead
questions.answerB: Right, toward the side of the road
questions.answerC: Left, toward the center of the road
questions.explanation: When parking either uphill or downhill on a road that has no curb, you should turn your wheels so that the vehicle will roll away from the center of the road if the brakes fail.

questions.question: At intersections, crosswalks, and railroad crossings, you should always:
questions.answerA: Stop, listen, and proceed cautiously.
questions.answerB: Look to the sides of your vehicle to see what is coming.
questions.answerC: Slowly pass vehicles that seem to be stopped for no reason.
questions.explanation: Any time you come to a place where people may cross or enter your path, or where one line of traffic meets another, you should look to the left and right sides of your vehicle to make sure no one is coming.

questions.question: Just like alcohol and other drugs, drowsiness can:
questions.answerA: Help you to be a better driver.
questions.answerB: Make you feel better.
questions.answerC: Impair your judgment.
questions.explanation: Not getting enough sleep is a cause of poor driving behavior. Just like drugs and alcohol, sleepiness slows reaction time, decreases awareness, and impairs judgment.

questions.question: Large trucks are likely to lose speed when:
questions.answerA: Driving up long or steep hills.
questions.answerB: Driving in long, gradual curves.
questions.answerC: Driving down long, gradual hills.
questions.explanation: Because large trucks require more time to accelerate than smaller vehicles, trucks can lose speed driving up long or steep hills. Be cautious when driving behind a large truck and be sure to give the vehicle additional space, especially when driving on an incline.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Divided highway.
questions.answerB: Railroad warning.
questions.answerC: No passing zone.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead.

questions.question: It is dangerous to follow a motorcycle too closely because:
questions.answerA: They do not follow the same rules as motor vehicles.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle can stop much faster than a standard vehicle.
questions.answerC: They brake more slowly than motor vehicles.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles can stop quickly and following them too closely endangers your life and that of the motorcyclist. If the motorcyclist makes a mistake, you need to have enough time and space to avoid a crash.

questions.question: A blood alcohol concentration of 0.02 percent:
questions.answerA: Won't have any effect on your driving.
questions.answerB: Won't put other drivers at risk.
questions.answerC: Will double your chances of having an accident.
questions.explanation: Every 0.02 percent increase in blood alcohol concentration nearly doubles a driver's risk of being in a fatal crash.

questions.question: You are approaching an intersection with a steady yellow traffic light. If you have not already entered the intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to beat the red light.
questions.answerB: Reduce you speed and proceed carefully through the intersection.
questions.answerC: Come to a safe stop.
questions.explanation: When a steady yellow light appears on a traffic signal, you should prepare to stop. If you are already within the intersection, you should clear the intersection as quickly as possible.

questions.question: An orange-colored sign like this means:
questions.answerA: There is roadwork ahead.
questions.answerB: You must change lanes ahead.
questions.answerC: There is a detour ahead.
questions.explanation: Orange-colored signs indicate construction areas. Proceed with caution.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Reserved parking for persons with disabilities.
questions.answerB: Slow-moving vehicle.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates parking spaces that are reserved for vehicles displaying Persons with Disabilities license plates, Disabled Veteran license plates, and/or disabled parking placards.

questions.question: When driving on a slippery surface, such as snow or ice:
questions.answerA: Shift to a low gear before going down steep hills.
questions.answerB: Maintain traction by following other vehicles closely.
questions.answerC: Pump your brakes to keep them from freezing.
questions.explanation: To prevent skidding on slippery surfaces, you should shift to a low gear before going down a steep hill. You should also follow farther behind the vehicle in front of you than you normally would. Quick stops should be avoided. Unless you have antilock brakes, pump the brakes to slow or stop.

questions.question: A solid yellow line next to a broken yellow line means that vehicles:
questions.answerA: Driving in both directions may pass.
questions.answerB: Next to the broken line may pass.
questions.answerC: Next to the solid line may pass.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions. A broken yellow line next to your driving lane means that you may pass.

questions.question: Excessive speed:
questions.answerA: Saves time so you can get to your destination more quickly.
questions.answerB: Helps you maneuver around obstacles.
questions.answerC: Increases the likelihood of serious bodily injury and death.
questions.explanation: Excessive speed is one of the most common contributing factors to vehicle crashes. Excessive speed does not save time and often leads to high-risk decision-making.

questions.question: In inclement weather, you should:
questions.answerA: Steer off the road.
questions.answerB: Drive in a low gear.
questions.answerC: Steer and brake smoothly.
questions.explanation: When driving during unfavorable weather conditions, avoid slamming on the brakes and making sharp, quick turns. These behaviors will make controlling your vehicle in inclement weather even more difficult.

questions.question: The proper way to make a right turn is to:
questions.answerA: Signal, slow down, and get into the lane closest to the centerline before turning.
questions.answerB: Signal, slow down, and get into the lane closest to the right curb before turning.
questions.answerC: Approach the corner in the lane nearest the right curb, but move over toward the middle of the street before turning.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a right turn, use the appropriate signal to give surrounding drivers adequate notice of your intentions. Slow down and approach the intersection from the right lane, staying as close as is practical to the right curb or edge of the roadway.

questions.question: When adjusting your rearview mirror, you should be able to clearly see:
questions.answerA: The entire rear window.
questions.answerB: The passengers in the backseat.
questions.answerC: Your own reflection.
questions.explanation: Adjust your inside rearview mirror so you can see the entire rear window from the driver's seat. You should have to move only your eyes, not your head, when using this mirror.

questions.question: Accumulating ____ on your license within a 24-month period will result in the suspension of your license.
questions.answerA: 15 points
questions.answerB: 22 points
questions.answerC: 30 points
questions.explanation: Certain offenses committed while driving will count against a driver in South Dakota's system of suspending driver licenses. If a driver accrues 22 points or more within a 24-month period, their license will be suspended. Lengths of suspension vary based on how many offenses the driver has committed.

questions.question: If you drive faster than other vehicles on a road with one lane moving in each direction and continually pass the other cars, you will:
questions.answerA: Get you to your destination much more quickly and safely.
questions.answerB: Increase your chances of an collision.
questions.answerC: Help prevent traffic congestion.
questions.explanation: You should avoid passing other vehicles on two-lane roads. Every time you pass a vehicle, your odds of being in a collision increase.

questions.question: When a school bus is picking up or dropping off children, you must:
questions.answerA: Stop, regardless of your direction of travel.
questions.answerB: Stop if you are driving in the same direction.
questions.answerC: Slow down and be prepared to stop.
questions.explanation: When approaching a school bus that is picking up or dropping off passengers, you must come to a complete stop before reaching the bus, regardless of your direction of travel.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you should stop and:
questions.answerA: Check for vehicles only in the direction that you plan on going, then proceed.
questions.answerB: Let all vehicles that arrive before or after you go first.
questions.answerC: Check for traffic in all directions before proceeding.
questions.explanation: At a stop sign, you must come to a full stop and check for traffic in all directions before proceeding.

questions.question: When driving behind another vehicle at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your headlights on the low beam setting.
questions.answerB: Use your high beam headlights until you are within 10 feet of the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerC: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Use high beam headlights only when driving in rural areas and when other cars are not nearby. Lower your headlights to their low beam setting when you are following closely behind another driver.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Hospital.
questions.answerB: Upcoming intersection.
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers of an upcoming intersection so they may prepare for potential traffic or prepare to turn.

questions.question: Which of the following are factors commonly contributing to traffic crashes?
questions.answerA: Exceeding the posted speed limit and driving too fast for conditions or circumstances.
questions.answerB: Getting adequate rest and staying alert.
questions.answerC: Scanning the environment and staying focused on the driving task.
questions.explanation: Driving above the speed limit, driving too far below the speed limit, and driving too fast for conditions are all actions that commonly contribute to traffic accidents. Always drive with the general flow of traffic, within legal speed limits.

questions.question: Extra space in front of a large truck is needed for:
questions.answerA: Other drivers to merge onto the freeway.
questions.answerB: The truck driver to stop the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Other drivers when they want to slow down.
questions.explanation: Because they are larger, trucks take longer to stop than cars traveling at the same speed. Other drivers should not pull in front of a truck and then slow down or stop.

questions.question: After passing a vehicle, it is safe to return to your driving lane when:
questions.answerA: The driver you passed signals for you to return to your lane.
questions.answerB: You signal your intention for three seconds.
questions.answerC: You see the headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
