questions.explanation: Before you return to your driving lane, be sure you are not dangerously close to the vehicle you have just passed. One way to do this is to look for the vehicle in your inside rearview mirror. When you can see both headlights in your rearview mirror, you may have enough room to return to your driving lane.

questions.question: Night driving presents unique problems because:
questions.answerA: The speed limit is increased at night.
questions.answerB: There are fewer cars on the roads at night.
questions.answerC: Distance and vehicle speed are difficult to judge in the dark.
questions.explanation: Night driving creates a unique set of problems for drivers. Due to the reduced visibility, it can be difficult to judge distance and the traveling speeds of other vehicles when driving at night. Drivers can see only as far as their headlights allow.

questions.question: You reach an intersection with stop signs on all four corners at the same time as the driver on your left. Who has the right-of-way?
questions.answerA: The driver on your left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: You have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Whoever is signaling to make a turn has the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: If two vehicles arrive at the same time to an intersection that has stop signs on all corners, the vehicle to the right has the right-of-way.

questions.question: Handicap parking spaces are available:
questions.answerA: To anyone, but only if all other spaces are occupied.
questions.answerB: Only to drivers with the appropriate license plate or hanging tag.
questions.answerC: To people who are not feeling well.
questions.explanation: Reserved handicap parking spaces should be used only by persons with a disability as defined under state law. To park in a handicap parking space, you must have either the appropriate license plate or designated hang tag displaying the international symbol.

questions.question: To avoid hydroplaning while driving in rainy conditions, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive at a speed appropriate for ideal conditions.
questions.answerB: Apply your brakes as soon as your car starts to skid.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: When driving too quickly in wet conditions, your tires may lose all contact with the road surface. Loss of traction will cause the vehicle to ride on top of the water, which is called "hydroplaning." The best way to prevent this from happening is to drive more slowly in rainy or wet conditions than you would when driving during ideal weather conditions.

questions.question: When may you drive on the shoulder of the road?
questions.answerA: Only when told to do so by an official.
questions.answerB: When the car in front of you is driving too slowly.
questions.answerC: When the car in front of you is turning.
questions.explanation: If you pass on the right, do so only when conditions permit you to do so legally and safely. You may only drive on the shoulder of a road if an official has directed you to do so.

questions.question: You can drive off the road to pass another vehicle:
questions.answerA: If the vehicle ahead is turning left.
questions.answerB: If there are two or more lanes traveling in your direction.
questions.answerC: Under no circumstances.
questions.explanation: You may never drive off the paved or main-traveled portion of the road and onto the shoulder to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: You are merging onto an interstate highway. You should:
questions.answerA: Select a safe gap and merge into the lane of traffic.
questions.answerB: Merge across two lanes at once.
questions.answerC: Always stop before entering the highway.
questions.explanation: Anytime you want to merge with other drivers, you need to find a gap large enough for you to safely enter into the flow of traffic. You should not stop on the entrance ramp to an interstate highway unless there are no gaps into which you may safely merge.

questions.question: If you must park your vehicle in an area not usually used for parking:
questions.answerA: Park with your reverse lights on.
questions.answerB: Make sure your vehicle is visible to drivers approaching from any direction.
questions.answerC: Park five feet from the curb.
questions.explanation: Drivers are responsible for making sure their vehicles do not become hazards after they have been parked. Wherever you park, make sure your car is visible to drivers approaching from any direction.

questions.question: A broken yellow line down the center of a road indicates that:
questions.answerA: A construction zone is ahead.
questions.answerB: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerC: Passing is permitted from either direction.
questions.explanation: When broken yellow lines separate the lanes of traffic on a two-lane roadway, any driver may pass when there is no oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Should you always drive more slowly than other traffic?
questions.answerA: No, you can block traffic when you drive too slowly.
questions.answerB: Yes, it is a good defensive driving technique.
questions.answerC: Yes, it is always safer than driving faster than other traffic.
questions.explanation: You must drive more slowly than usual when there is heavy traffic or bad weather. However, if you block the normal and reasonable movement of traffic by driving too slowly, you may be cited.

questions.question: Using a cell phone while operating a motor vehicle is considered a distraction because:
questions.answerA: It causes the driver to be concerned about the cost of the call.
questions.answerB: It occupies the driver's hands, eyes, and mind.
questions.answerC: It is an activity that draws the attention of other drivers.
questions.explanation: Using a cell phone while driving is dangerous because it occupies the user's eyes, hands, and mind. Even the most skilled drivers increase their risk of being involved in a crash by using a cell phone on the road.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and use your low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Slow down and use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights on and off to warn other drivers.
questions.explanation: When driving in fog, you should slow down and use your low beam headlights. If the fog is so bad that you cannot see, pull off the road and wait for the fog to clear.

questions.question: On a multilane road, a dashed yellow line next to a solid yellow line means:
questions.answerA: Passing is prohibited from both directions.
questions.answerB: Passing is permitted from both directions.
questions.answerC: Passing is permitted only from the direction next to the dashed line.
questions.explanation: Where there are both solid and dashed yellow lines between lanes of traffic, only traffic directly next to the dashed line may cross the centerline to pass. Drivers next to the solid line may not pass.

questions.question: If you plan to pass another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Not assume the other driver will make space for you to return to your lane.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver will let you pass if you use your turn signal.
questions.answerC: Assume the other driver will maintain a constant speed.
questions.explanation: Even when you signal, you should not assume that the space you want to occupy is free or that other drivers will give you the right-of-way.

questions.question: To prevent yourself from becoming an aggressive driver:
questions.answerA: Relax and concentrate on driving.
questions.answerB: Drive above the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Tailgate the driver in front of you.
questions.explanation: To prevent yourself from becoming an aggressive driver, concentrate on driving and don't take the actions of other drivers personally. Be realistic about your travel time, drive within posted speed limits, and be forgiving of other drivers using the roadway.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Four-lane traffic ahead.
questions.answerB: Divided highway ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns that you are leaving a separated one-way highway and will soon be driving on a two-way highway.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should return to your original lane when:
questions.answerA: You can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: You have cleared the front bumper of the passed vehicle.
questions.answerC: You are 50 feet in front of the passed vehicle.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle, move back into your original lane only when you can see the passed vehicle’s headlights in your rearview mirror. This ensures that you will have enough room to safely pull back in front of the other vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following substances can affect the ability to drive?
questions.answerA: Tranquilizers, marijuana, and sedatives.
questions.answerB: Cough syrups and cold tablets containing codeine or antihistamines.
questions.answerC: All of the above.
questions.explanation: A number of drugs can impair your ability to drive, including depressant medications like tranquilizers and sedatives; over-the-counter cough syrups, cold tablets, and allergy medications (which may contain impairing substances like alcohol, codeine, or antihistamines); and illegal drugs.

questions.question: What message will be found on this yellow pennant-shaped sign?
questions.answerA: Right turns only.
questions.answerB: Right turns permitted.
questions.answerC: No passing zone.
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped yellow signs like this are used to indicate a no passing zone.

questions.question: Remove all snow, frost, and ice from:
questions.answerA: Just the windshield.
questions.answerB: All windows.
questions.answerC: Just the windshield and passenger window.
questions.explanation: It is important that you are able to see clearly through all of your vehicle's windows, including the windshield. Remove all snow, ice, and frost from your vehicle's windows and mirrors before you start to drive.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Flagger ahead.
questions.answerB: Turn left at the intersection.
questions.answerC: Last turn before a toll road.
questions.explanation: Orange is the standard color for work zone activity. If you see orange signs, cones, or barrels while driving, stay alert and be prepared for unexpected driving conditions. This sign alerts drivers to an upcoming flagger whose directions should be obeyed by all drivers.

questions.question: If the driver of an oncoming vehicle fails to dim their headlights:
questions.answerA: Look toward the center of the roadway.
questions.answerB: Look toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerC: Look straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If an oncoming driver fails to dim their headlights, look toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and allow you to see enough of the road to stay on course. Do not try to retaliate by keeping your bright lights on.

questions.question: When passing another car, you have enough space to return to the driving lane:
questions.answerA: If the other driver signals for you to re-enter the lane.
questions.answerB: If you look over your shoulder and see the passed car behind you.
questions.answerC: If you can see both of the passed vehicle's headlights in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Before you return to the driving lane when completing a pass, be sure there is a safe gap between your vehicle and the passed vehicle. When you can see both headlights of the vehicle in your rearview mirror, it is safe to return to the driving lane.

questions.question: When are drivers required to use their headlights?
questions.answerA: One half hour after sunset until one half hour before sunrise
questions.answerB: During the day in clear weather
questions.answerC: When they are tired
questions.explanation: Headlights must be used from one half hour after sunset until one half hour before sunrise. They must also be used at any other time when visibility is less than 200 feet.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Steep grade ahead.
questions.answerB: The road ahead winds with a series of turns or curves.
questions.answerC: Slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers to be careful when driving under wet conditions as the pavement will become slippery and more difficult to navigate safely.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about drinking alcohol and driving?
questions.answerA: If you can walk in a straight line after drinking, it is safe to drive.
questions.answerB: If you are under the legal blood alcohol concentration limit, your driving isn't impaired.
questions.answerC: Alcohol affects judgement, which is needed to drive safely.
questions.explanation: Being under the influence of alcohol affects your judgment. Good judgement is necessary to react appropriately to things that you see or hear while on the road. Even if you are below the legal blood alcohol limit, consuming any amount of alcohol is likely to affect your ability to drive safely.

questions.question: The amount of alcohol in the blood is referred to as:
questions.answerA: Implied consent (IC).
questions.answerB: Blood alcohol concentration (BAC).
questions.answerC: Rate of alcohol consumption (RAC).
questions.explanation: Blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is a measurement of the percentage of alcohol in the blood. The higher the BAC number, the more impaired a person is.

questions.question: If you approach a stopped school bus that has its lights flashing and signal arm extended, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: Proceed at 15 mph if no children are present.
questions.answerC: Proceed at normal speed, but watch for children.
questions.explanation: If you approach a stopped school bus that has its lights flashing and arm extended, you must come to a full stop and remain stopped until the signal arm is pulled back and the bus resumes motion. This law applies whether you are traveling in the same direction as the bus or if you are approaching from the opposite side of the street.

questions.question: Drivers turning left must yield to:
questions.answerA: Overtaking cars.
questions.answerB: Oncoming cars.
questions.answerC: No one.
questions.explanation: Drivers turning left must yield to oncoming vehicles that are driving straight ahead. A turning driver may only proceed when they can safely turn without affecting oncoming traffic.

questions.question: To turn left from a multilane one-way street onto a one-way street, you should start your turn from:
questions.answerA: Any lane (as long as it is safe).
questions.answerB: The lane closest to the left curb.
questions.answerC: The lane in the center of the road.
questions.explanation: When turning left from a one-way street onto another one-way street, you should begin the turn from the far left lane.

questions.question: This bicyclist is signaling:
questions.answerA: A left turn.
questions.answerB: An upcoming stop.
questions.answerC: A right turn.
questions.explanation: Bicycles do not have turn signals so bicyclists use hand and arm signals to alert other drivers to their intentions. If a bicyclist puts their left arm straight out, they are signaling that they intend to turn left.

questions.question: If you are driving and the rear end of your car starts skidding to the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Steer to the right.
questions.answerB: Steer to the left.
questions.answerC: Tap your brakes lightly and shift into neutral.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle enters a skid, you should take your foot off of the brake and steer in the direction that you want to go. For example, if the rear of your vehicle is skidding to the left, you should steer to the left. This will help bring the front of the vehicle in line with the rear, thereby straightening out the vehicle's overall direction.

questions.question: Roads with double solid yellow line markings down the center indicate that passing is:
questions.answerA: Allowed from both directions.
questions.answerB: Allowed only from your direction of travel.
questions.answerC: Not allowed from either direction.
questions.explanation: A double solid yellow line down the center of a road indicates that traffic is moving in opposite directions and that passing is not allowed from either direction.

questions.question: This symbol is used for:
questions.answerA: Dangerous intersections.
questions.answerB: Slow-moving vehicles.
questions.answerC: Yield signs.
questions.explanation: A reflective orange triangle on the rear of a vehicle means it travels only at slow speeds. You may see this sign on roadwork equipment, farm vehicles, or horse-drawn wagons and carriages. It appears as a solid orange triangle during the day and a hollow red triangle at night.

questions.question: When backing up:
questions.answerA: Look through the rear window.
questions.answerB: Press hard on the gas pedal.
questions.answerC: Rely only on your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When backing up, place your right arm on the back of the passenger seat and look directly through the rear window. Do not depend on your rearview or side mirrors as mirrors do not show directly behind your vehicle. Only drive in reverse at a low speed.

questions.question: When driving on gravel or dirt roads:
questions.answerA: Your tires grip the road better than when you are driving on pavement.
questions.answerB: Your tires do not have as much traction as they do on pavement, so you must slow down.
questions.answerC: Visibility is better than on pavement.
questions.explanation: Your tires do not have as much traction on loose gravel and dirt roads as they do on concrete and asphalt roads. When driving on gravel or dirt, you must slow down. It will take you much longer to stop and it is much easier to skid when turning.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop Sign Ahead.
questions.answerB: Side Road.
questions.answerC: Railroad Warning.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a stop sign is ahead.

questions.question: This sign means you are approaching a railroad crossing that does not have a signal. You should:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Proceed at a consistent speed while looking and listening for approaching trains.
questions.answerC: Slow down, look both ways, listen for any trains, and be prepared to stop if any trains are nearby.
questions.explanation: At a railroad crossing marked with this sign, a driver should look both ways, listen for any trains, and be prepared to stop if any trains are nearby. Never try to outdrive an oncoming train.

questions.question: If you come to an intersection and your view to the side is blocked, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and look both ways.
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed and look both ways.
questions.answerC: Stop, then inch forward until you can see clearly in both directions.
questions.explanation: Drivers must slow down when approaching an intersection. If a clear view of cross traffic is obscured, a driver should come to a stop and inch forward until they can see clearly in both directions.

questions.question: This yellow sign means:
questions.answerA: One lane ahead.
questions.answerB: Merging traffic ahead.
questions.answerC: Lane ends ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of the possible presence of merging traffic.

questions.question: If you come to an intersection controlled by a flashing yellow light, you must:
questions.answerA: Wait for the green light before proceeding.
questions.answerB: Slow down and cross the intersection carefully.
questions.answerC: Stop before crossing the intersection.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow traffic light means drivers must slow down, be more aware, and proceed with caution. Be alert to crossing traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: This sign shows one type of:
questions.answerA: Intersection.
questions.answerB: Road curve.
questions.answerC: Right turn.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers that another road crosses the highway ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You can travel in either direction in this lane.
questions.answerB: There is two-way traffic.
questions.answerC: You are approaching a divided highway.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of two-way traffic.

questions.question: If you are being passed in a no passing zone, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull off the road.
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed and position.
questions.answerC: Slow down and let the other driver safely return to the drive lane.
questions.explanation: Passing areas are based on how far ahead drivers can see. Allow the passing vehicle to re-enter the drive lane as easily as possible to help everyone avoid potential upcoming hazards.

questions.question: When stopped for a traffic violation, a driver must produce:
questions.answerA: Only their insurance and registration.
questions.answerB: Only their license.
questions.answerC: Their license, insurance, and registration.
questions.explanation: When stopped for a traffic violation, a driver must produce their license, proof of registration, and proof of insurance. Drivers are required to have all three of these documents in a vehicle any time it is being driven.

questions.question: Having a driver license is a:
questions.answerA: Right, not a privilege.
questions.answerB: Privilege, not a right.
questions.answerC: Requirement.
questions.explanation: Holding a driver license is not a right. It is a privilege that must be earned and maintained.

questions.question: What is a potential effect of taking a prescription drug while drinking alcohol?
questions.answerA: There will likely be no effect.
questions.answerB: It will make you more alert.
questions.answerC: It can make you unfit to drive.
questions.explanation: Legal medications, both prescription and over-the-counter, can impair your ability to drive. They can be particularly dangerous when used in combination with alcohol.

questions.question: If your car begins to skid out of control, you should:
questions.answerA: Pump the brakes.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes lightly.
questions.answerC: Stay off the brakes.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to skid, stay off the brakes. Continue to correct your steering until the vehicle is back under your control and moving safely down the road.

questions.question: What is the only effective way to remove alcohol from the body?
questions.answerA: Drink strong coffee.
questions.answerB: Wait.
questions.answerC: Take a cold shower.
questions.explanation: The only way to remove the effects of alcohol from the body is to let time pass. Eating, drinking coffee, or taking a shower will not speed up this process.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection controlled by a flashing yellow light, you must:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop at the intersection.
questions.answerB: Maintain your normal speed.
questions.answerC: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.explanation: A traffic signal displaying a flashing yellow light indicates that you should be alert and proceed with caution. Slow down when approaching a flashing yellow traffic signal.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked vehicles, you should:
questions.answerA: Be prepared for a person or vehicle to unexpectedly enter your lane.
questions.answerB: Expect all other drivers and pedestrians to respect your right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Drive closely to the parked vehicles to allow more room for moving traffic.
questions.explanation: Keep a space between your vehicle and parked vehicles. A person may step out of a parked vehicle or out from between the parked vehicles without looking. A driver may begin moving their vehicle before realizing you are there.

questions.question: When parallel parking, you should park within ____ of the curb.
questions.answerA: Three feet
questions.answerB: Two feet
questions.answerC: One foot
questions.explanation: When parallel parking, your wheels should be parallel to and within one foot of the curb. Only park where you will not be disruptive to traffic and where drivers can clearly see your vehicle from both directions.

questions.question: After you have passed a vehicle moving in the same direction, it is safe to move back into the right lane:
questions.answerA: After about three seconds.
questions.answerB: When you can no longer see the passed vehicle over your right shoulder.
questions.answerC: When you can see the entire front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When passing, you should not return to your original lane until you can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror. Always check your blind spots before moving back into your original lane.

questions.question: You exit the freeway on a ramp that curves downhill. You should:
questions.answerA: Slow to a safe speed before the curve.
questions.answerB: Slow to the posted speed limit for the freeway.
questions.answerC: Wait until you have entered the curve to begin braking.
questions.explanation: You should always slow down before entering a curve. You may not be able to see hazards ahead and braking in a curve may cause your vehicle to skid.

questions.question: Construction zone signs are generally:
questions.answerA: Square or rectangular with white and red coloring.
questions.answerB: Round or octagonal with black and yellow coloring.
questions.answerC: Diamond-shaped or rectangular with orange and black coloring.
questions.explanation: All temporary signs in work zones have an orange background with black letters or symbols. These signs are found on the right side of the road, or on both the left and right sides if the roadway is a divided highway.

questions.question: When driving in work zones, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to get through the zone as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed and be prepared to stop suddenly.
questions.answerC: Maintain your normal speed the whole way through the zone.
questions.explanation: When entering and driving through a work zone, slow down and be prepared to stop. Obey posted speed limits and be alert to conditions around you. Workers could be present.

questions.question: What is the only medically proven method of removing alcohol or other drug combinations from your system?
questions.answerA: Breathe in some fresh air.
questions.answerB: Give your body time.
questions.answerC: Drink coffee.
questions.explanation: Alcohol takes effect quickly and is slow to leave your system. Cold showers, black coffee, and exercise will do nothing to reduce a person's blood alcohol content (BAC). The only way to lower your BAC is to wait.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Watch for traffic merging from the right.
questions.answerB: Merge right.
questions.answerC: Turn left.
questions.explanation: Warning signs alert drivers to upcoming hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers about potential traffic merging into their lane from the right.

questions.question: If you drive more slowly than the flow of traffic, you will most likely:
questions.answerA: Interfere with traffic and receive a ticket.
questions.answerB: Improve traffic flow.
questions.answerC: Demonstrate defensive driving techniques.
questions.explanation: You must drive more slowly than usual when there is heavy traffic or bad weather. However, if you block the normal and reasonable movement of traffic by driving too slowly, you may be cited. You should match the speed of traffic, unless the speed of traffic exceeds the legal speed limit.

questions.question: When you see a flashing yellow light at an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Yield to all traffic before crossing the intersection.
questions.answerB: Stop, then enter the intersection when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Slow down and cross the intersection carefully.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light at an intersection indicates that drivers should slow to a safe and reasonable speed and proceed with caution.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Highway entrance ramp.
questions.answerB: Road widens.
questions.answerC: Right lane ends.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to the right lane ending and tells them to prepare for potential merging traffic.

questions.question: A broken yellow line beside a solid yellow line indicates that passing is:
questions.answerA: Permitted from the side next to the solid yellow line.
questions.answerB: Not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerC: Permitted from the side next to the broken yellow line.
questions.explanation: When the center of the road is marked by a solid yellow line beside a broken yellow line, passing is permitted from the side next to the broken line and prohibited from the side next to the solid line.

questions.question: Before switching on the ignition, you should:
questions.answerA: Buckle your safety belt.
questions.answerB: Be sure all passengers have buckled their safety belts.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Develop a routine for entering and leaving your car. Before switching on the ignition, buckle your safety belt and see that all passengers do likewise.

questions.question: To know where traffic is behind you:
questions.answerA: Frequently check your rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Turn and look out your back window.
questions.answerC: Keep other vehicles out of your blind spots.
questions.explanation: Drivers should check their rearview mirrors often to stay aware of the position of traffic behind them.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Cars on the right move first.
questions.answerB: You have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Let cross traffic pass before proceeding.
questions.explanation: When approaching this sign, you must yield the right-of-way. Slow down and let vehicles and pedestrians crossing your path pass before you proceed. If necessary, stop before going ahead.

questions.question: You are entering a freeway. Check traffic on the freeway by:
questions.answerA: Using your rearview and side mirrors.
questions.answerB: Using your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Using your side mirror and looking over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: When entering any roadway, you must be aware of traffic conditions. Use your side mirror and look over your shoulder to help you see and anticipate traffic when entering a freeway.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Drive with caution and be ready to stop.
questions.answerB: You must come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Stop, if necessary.
questions.explanation: The stop sign is the only eight-sided sign you will see on any roadway. When you encounter a stop sign, you must come to a complete stop. You may not proceed until the way is clear for you to completely and safely pass through the intersection.

questions.question: If bad weather makes it difficult for you to see clearly, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to get off the road quickly.
questions.answerB: Drive in the lane closest to oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: When it is difficult to see due to darkness or poor weather, increase your following distance. This will give you more time to react to hazards that you may not see in advance.

questions.question: You must obey instructions from school crossing guards:
questions.answerA: At all times.
questions.answerB: Only during school hours.
questions.answerC: Unless you do not see any children present.
questions.explanation: Drivers should be alert to the presence of crossing guards when near a school and must always obey their instructions.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about large trucks?
questions.answerA: They take longer to stop than passenger vehicles.
questions.answerB: They all have air brakes that allow them to stop quickly.
questions.answerC: They are more maneuverable than passenger vehicles.
questions.explanation: Large trucks take longer to stop than other vehicles traveling at the same speed. The average passenger vehicle traveling at 55 mph can stop within 400 feet. However, a large truck traveling at the same speed can take almost 800 feet to stop.

questions.question: There is no crosswalk and you see a pedestrian crossing your lane ahead. You should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with and then pass the pedestrian.
questions.answerB: Slow down as you pass the pedestrian.
questions.answerC: Stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing the street.
questions.explanation: At an intersection where traffic is not controlled by traffic signal lights, drivers are required to yield the right-of-way to pedestrians within any crosswalk, marked or unmarked. Even if there is no crosswalk, yield to the pedestrian.

questions.question: If you are facing a green traffic light but the intersection ahead is blocked by traffic, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn left and find another route.
questions.answerB: Stay out of the intersection until traffic clears.
questions.answerC: Follow the other vehicles and enter the intersection.
questions.explanation: Even if you are facing a green traffic light, do not start across the intersection if there are other vehicles blocking your way. If you are caught in the intersection when the light changes to red, your vehicle will block cross traffic. You can get a ticket for blocking an intersection.

questions.question: If you have trouble seeing other vehicles because of dust or smoke blowing across the roadway, you should drive more slowly and turn on your:
questions.answerA: Emergency flashers.
questions.answerB: Parking lights.
questions.answerC: Headlights.
questions.explanation: You must turn on your headlights any time conditions prevent you from seeing other vehicles. Other drivers may have trouble seeing you, too.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: No right turn.
questions.answerB: Drive only in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerC: Curve ahead.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs provide notice to road users of traffic laws that must be obeyed. Where this sign is present, drivers must drive in the direction indicated by the arrow.

questions.question: Children on bicycles should be given extra space by motor vehicle operators because:
questions.answerA: They do not have the same physical reflexes as adults.
questions.answerB: They are smaller and more difficult to see than adults.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Children are often the least predictable pedestrians and the most difficult pedestrians to see. Take extra care to look out for children, especially near schools, bus stops, playgrounds, parks, and ice cream trucks. Be aware of children riding bikes on the sidewalk, as they may come onto the road unexpectedly.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Do not enter.
questions.answerB: Roundabout ahead.
questions.answerC: No U-turns.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs provide notice to road users of traffic laws that must be obeyed. This sign tells drivers that it is prohibited to make a U-turn.

questions.question: It is unlawful to:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle in any marked no passing zone.
questions.answerB: Pass another vehicle over a railroad crossing.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to cross the centerline to pass when driving on hills, in curves, and in other locations where you cannot see ahead far enough to pass safely. You may not pass at street crossings, at railroad crossings, where signs indicate no passing zones, or where a solid yellow line is next to your lane. You may not pass when the vehicle in front of you has stopped for a pedestrian or when driving in work zones where passing would be hazardous.

questions.question: Alcohol in any concentration is:
questions.answerA: A stimulant.
questions.answerB: A depressant.
questions.answerC: Neither of the above.
questions.explanation: Alcohol, in any concentration, is a depressant. It slows all nerve impulses and bodily functions, resulting in a lessening of inhibitions and negatively affecting a consumer's ability to concentrate and stay alert.

questions.question: A solid yellow arrow on a traffic signal means:
questions.answerA: You should speed up so you can make the turn before the light changes.
questions.answerB: You do not need to signal to turn from the indicated lane.
questions.answerC: You should prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: A solid yellow arrow means that the protection of a green arrow is ending. If you are turning in the direction of the arrow, you should prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic before turning.

questions.question: The maximum posted speed limit should be driven only:
questions.answerA: During the night.
questions.answerB: During the day.
questions.answerC: Under ideal conditions.
questions.explanation: The posted maximum speed limit is the fastest legal speed you can travel on a road under ideal conditions. It is safest to drive at the same speed as surrounding traffic, up to the maximum speed limit. Maintaining a safe speed at all times is a responsibility shared by all motorists.

questions.question: It is legal to make a left turn at a red traffic light after stopping only if:
questions.answerA: You are traveling on a two-way street and turning onto a two-way street.
questions.answerB: You are traveling on a one-way street and turning onto another one-way street.
questions.answerC: You yield to all other traffic at the intersection.
questions.explanation: After coming to a complete stop, you may turn left at a red light only if you are traveling on a one-way street and turning onto another one-way street. Only make the turn if there are no posted signs prohibiting such a turn.

questions.question: A school bus is stopped ahead of you in your lane with its red lights flashing. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop and proceed when you think all of the children have exited the bus.
questions.answerB: Slow to 25 mph and pass cautiously.
questions.answerC: Stop for as long as the red lights are flashing.
questions.explanation: When a stopped school bus is using its flashing red lights, approaching drivers must stop and remain stopped until the lights stop flashing. If the school bus is on the opposite side of a divided highway, drivers do not need to stop.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: Slow down and prepare to stop if cars are approaching you.
questions.answerB: Come to a full stop then proceed when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Proceed carefully through the intersection, not always stopping.
questions.explanation: An octagonal sign always means stop. When approaching a stop sign, you must come to a complete stop at the marked stop line and proceed only when it is safe to do so. If there is no stop line, stop before the crosswalk. If there is no crosswalk, stop before the intersection at a point from which you can see any oncoming traffic.

questions.question: The best thing to do if you become tired while driving is to:
questions.answerA: Stop to rest or change drivers.
questions.answerB: Drink coffee.
questions.answerC: Open a window.
questions.explanation: If you become tired while driving, it is best to stop to rest or change drivers. Being tired dulls your mind and slows down your reactions, making driving hazardous.

questions.question: Tailgating other drivers (driving too closely to their rear bumper):
questions.answerA: Can frustrate other drivers and make them angry.
questions.answerB: Cannot result in a traffic citation.
questions.answerC: Reduces collisions by preventing being "cut off."
questions.explanation: Tailgating is a common behavior that can lead to aggressive driving, and so it should be avoided. Drivers may face legal consequences for driving unsafely.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerB: School crossing.
questions.answerC: Jogging trail.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers to be alert to crossing pedestrians.

questions.question: Which of the following road surfaces freezes first?
questions.answerA: A tunnel
questions.answerB: An intersection
questions.answerC: A bridge
questions.explanation: Pavement on bridges and overpasses can become icy even when other surrounding pavement is dry. Bridges often freeze before, and thaw out after, the rest of a road.

questions.question: If your vehicle has a two-part safety belt system, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the lap belt.
questions.answerB: Use both the lap and shoulder belts.
questions.answerC: Use only the shoulder belt.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has a two-part seat belt system, be sure to wear both the lap belt and the shoulder belt. Wearing either part alone greatly reduces your protection. If you have an automatic shoulder belt, be sure to buckle your lap belt as well.

questions.question: You should yield to a pedestrian:
questions.answerA: Only if they are in a crosswalk.
questions.answerB: At all times, even if the pedestrian is not obeying traffic laws.
questions.answerC: Only if the traffic lights are in the pedestrian's favor.
questions.explanation: Always be aware of pedestrians near your vehicle. You must do everything you can to prevent striking a pedestrian, regardless of the circumstances.

questions.question: Refusing to take an alcohol analysis test when requested to do so by law enforcement:
questions.answerA: Will result in license suspension.
questions.answerB: Is your right and will have no negative consequences.
questions.answerC: Is recommended.
questions.explanation: If you are driving a motor vehicle in South Dakota, you automatically consent to a test determining the presence of alcohol, or any other abused controlled substance, in your blood. If you refuse to submit to the test, your driving privileges will be suspended.

questions.question: The driver ahead of you stops at a crosswalk. What should you do?
questions.answerA: Cautiously pass the vehicle at 10 mph or slower.
questions.answerB: Stop, proceeding only when all the pedestrians have crossed.
questions.answerC: Change lanes, look carefully, and pass the stopped vehicle.
questions.explanation: You must not pass a vehicle that is stopped at a crosswalk. There may be pedestrians crossing the street that you cannot see. Instead, stop, proceeding only after all pedestrians have crossed.

questions.question: When a school bus is stopped ahead on your side of the road with its red lights flashing, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow to a speed no faster than 10 mph.
questions.answerB: Stop until the lights stop flashing.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and pass cautiously.
questions.explanation: The flashing overhead lights and stop arm on a school bus will be activated when the bus is stopped to load or unload students. If approaching a bus using these signals, you may not proceed until the red lights have stopped flashing and the stop arm has been retracted. Never pass a school bus that is dropping off or picking up students.

questions.question: You should always travel:
questions.answerA: At the speed of vehicles surrounding you.
questions.answerB: At the speed limit.
questions.answerC: At a speed appropriate for road and weather conditions.
questions.explanation: The speed at which you should drive your vehicle depends on road conditions, the weather, and the legal speed limit. You may never drive above the legal speed limit. Decrease your speed when anything makes conditions less than ideal.

questions.question: You drive defensively when you:
questions.answerA: Put one car length between you and the car ahead.
questions.answerB: Look only at the car in front of you while driving.
questions.answerC: Keep your eyes moving to look for possible hazards.
questions.explanation: You are driving defensively when you are looking down the road for potential hazards. Constantly staring at the road directly in front of your vehicle is dangerous. As you scan ahead, be alert to vehicles around you.

questions.question: When crossing a sidewalk to enter traffic from an alley or driveway, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Stop only if pedestrians are on the sidewalk.
questions.answerB: Stop before driving onto the sidewalk or sidewalk area.
questions.answerC: Expect pedestrians on the sidewalk to yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: When leaving an alley, driveway, or parking lot to enter a roadway, you must stop before driving onto a sidewalk or sidewalk area. Pedestrians and existing traffic have the right-of-way.

questions.question: You have stopped for a train at a railroad crossing. After the train passes, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait for signal lights to stop flashing.
questions.answerB: Look for a second train.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Even after a train passes, watch out for a second train approaching on any track. Do not proceed until all gates have been lifted and all warning signals have stopped flashing.

questions.question: When driving on an interstate, to avoid traffic merging from on-ramps to your right, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes to the left.
questions.answerB: Slow down.
questions.answerC: Maintain your speed and position.
questions.explanation: When driving on an interstate highway, be aware of upcoming on-ramps. When traffic permits, move out of the right-hand lane to allow vehicles to enter from the on-ramps to your right.

questions.question: When preparing to make a left turn from a two-way street, you should drive:
questions.answerA: Near the right-hand side of the road.
questions.answerB: Near the centerline.
questions.answerC: On the left of the centerline.
questions.explanation: When you are turning left from a two-way street, begin in the lane closest to the centerline and start your turn just before the front of your car reaches the center of the intersection. Do not cut the corner. Steering hand-over-hand, turn into the first available legal lane.

questions.question: Vehicles stopped behind a school bus with its red lights flashing must remain stopped until:
questions.answerA: All students are off the bus.
questions.answerB: The stop arm is retracted.
questions.answerC: The stop arm is retracted and the bus resumes motion.
questions.explanation: When a school bus is flashing its red lights and has its stop arm extended, motorists must come to a full stop until the lights are turned off, the stop arm is withdrawn, and the bus begins moving again.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should never:
questions.answerA: Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot.
questions.answerB: Change lanes abruptly or spontaneously.
questions.answerC: Check for other vehicles moving into the same lane.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, you must be sure that there are no vehicles in the space you want to enter. Check for other vehicles behind and to the side of your vehicle by checking your mirrors and blind spots. Always use the proper turn signal before changing lanes to allow surrounding vehicles time to react to your movements.

questions.question: This sign tells a driver that:
questions.answerA: A construction flagger is ahead.
questions.answerB: A police officer is ahead.
questions.answerC: A parking attendant is ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that there is a flag person ahead. Always follow directions given by a flagger. Flaggers normally wear orange or yellow vests, yellow-green shirts, or bright jackets. They use paddles and red flags to direct traffic through the work zone and to let workers or construction vehicles cross the road.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: All traffic must turn left.
questions.answerB: No left turn.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign means drivers cannot make a left turn. It is unsafe and unlawful to make a left turn at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: Prior to entering a curve:
questions.answerA: Activate your turn signal.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerC: Brake hard.
questions.explanation: You may drive more slowly than the posted speed limit, based on road conditions, but it is illegal to drive any faster than the posted speed limit. Some conditions which require reduced speed for safety include approaching curves or hills where visibility is limited, driving on slippery roads, and driving on roads where animals and pedestrians are present.

questions.question: You use your horn:
questions.answerA: Whenever it may help prevent a collision.
questions.answerB: To get other drivers moving in a traffic jam.
questions.answerC: When you're angry with another driver.
questions.explanation: Other drivers cannot see you unless they are looking your way. Your horn may get their attention. Use it whenever it will help prevent a collision.

questions.question: When driving in a construction zone:
questions.answerA: Slightly increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Expect the unexpected.
questions.answerC: Expect construction workers to yield to motorists.
questions.explanation: You may encounter unexpected conditions in a construction zone. For the safety of yourself, other drivers, and construction workers, drive with extraordinary caution.

questions.question: Driving under the influence of any medication which impairs your driving is permitted:
questions.answerA: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerB: If you don't feel drowsy.
questions.answerC: If it is prescribed by a physician.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to drive under the influence of any substance that impairs your ability to drive safely. This includes alcohol, prescription medications, over-the-counter medications, and illegal drugs.

questions.question: If you want to enter the freeway but you don't see a gap in traffic, you should:
questions.answerA: Maintain your speed and force the other drivers to create a gap.
questions.answerB: Slow down on the ramp to wait for a gap.
questions.answerC: Stop at the end of the ramp to wait for a gap.
questions.explanation: If you want to enter the freeway but do not see a space for your vehicle in traffic, slow down on the ramp to wait for a gap. Do not drive to the end of the ramp and wait for a gap or you will not have enough room to accelerate to the speed of traffic before entering the roadway.

questions.question: To avoid glare from the headlights of an approaching car:
questions.answerA: Look briefly toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerB: Stay focused on the centerline on the road.
questions.answerC: Flash your high beams.
questions.explanation: You should avoid looking toward the bright lights of an oncoming vehicle by glancing toward the right side of the road. After looking briefly toward the side of the road, continue looking ahead to check on the position of the other vehicle.

questions.question: When stopping on snow or ice, drivers who are operating vehicles equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) should:
questions.answerA: Pump the brakes.
questions.answerB: Press and hold the brake pedal firmly.
questions.answerC: Stay off the brakes and wait for the car to drift to a stop.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), a driver should press the brake pedal firmly when stopping on a snowy or icy surface. The ABS will pump the brakes more rapidly than a driver would be able to.

questions.question: Crosswalks are:
questions.answerA: Always indicated by pavement markings.
questions.answerB: Either indicated by pavement markings or are not marked at all.
questions.answerC: Always unmarked.
questions.explanation: Crosswalks exist whether the lines are marked or unmarked. You must stop behind a crosswalk to allow any pedestrians to cross.

questions.question: In traffic moving at 50 to 55 mph, you are least likely to have an accident if you:
questions.answerA: Drive a few miles per hour faster than most other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Stay within that speed range.
questions.answerC: Drive a few miles per hour slower than most other vehicles.
questions.explanation: You should adjust your speed to travel smoothly with the other traffic on a roadway (provided that the other traffic is driving within the posted speed limits). Remember that vehicles moving in the same direction at the same speed cannot hit each other. Crashes involving multiple vehicles often happen when some vehicles are traveling at different speeds than others.

questions.question: If you can see that the roadway up ahead is covered by heavy smoke, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on your four-way flashers and continue.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed, move as far to the right as possible, and stop off the roadway.
questions.answerC: Turn on your high beam headlights and continue.
questions.explanation: If you notice that the road ahead is covered by heavy smoke, reduce your speed immediately, drive as far as possible to the right, and stop off the roadway. Only then should you determine if it is safe for you to continue. Remember that certain kinds of smoke can irritate your eyes and lungs or even kill you.

questions.question: A steady yellow traffic signal light is a warning that the light is about to change to red. If you are already within the intersection when a green light changes to yellow, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: Continue moving and clear the intersection safely.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed so as not to cause an accident.
questions.explanation: If you are already within an intersection when the traffic light turns yellow, you should clear the intersection as quickly as possible.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about blind spots is true?
questions.answerA: They are eliminated if you have one outside mirror on each side of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Large trucks have bigger blind spots than most passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Blind spots can be checked by looking in your rearview mirrors.
questions.explanation: Blind spots are areas that a driver cannot see if they look in their mirrors. Large trucks have large blind spots that drivers of other vehicles should avoid.

questions.question: When driving at night on a dimly lit street, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive slowly enough that you can stop within the area illuminated by your headlights.
questions.answerB: Turn on your high beam headlights to better see the vehicles ahead of you.
questions.answerC: Keep the instrument panel lights bright to be more visible to other drivers.
questions.explanation: You should drive more slowly at night than during the day because it is not possible to see as far ahead at night. You should make sure that you can stop within the area illuminated by your headlights.

questions.question: Increase your following distance when driving behind a large vehicle:
questions.answerA: To better see around the sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Because other drivers tend to pull behind large vehicles before trying to pass them.
questions.answerC: Because following too closely will get you caught in the vehicle's slipstream.
questions.explanation: Drivers of trucks, buses, vans, and any vehicles pulling campers or trailers may not be able to see you if you are driving directly behind them. Increase your following distance when driving behind one of these vehicles. Additionally, large vehicles can block your view of the road, so increase your following distance to look around the sides of the vehicle and see the road ahead.

questions.question: When you are behind a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Be ready to use your horn.
questions.answerB: Drive more slowly.
questions.answerC: Allow a larger following distance.
questions.explanation: When following a motorcyclist, allow for at least a three- to four-second following distance. Motorcycles can stop quickly and following them too closely endangers your life and that of the motorcyclist. If the motorcyclist should fall, you need extra distance to avoid the rider. The chances of a fall are greatest on wet and icy roads, gravel roads, and metal surfaces such as bridges, gratings, and streetcar or railroad tracks.

questions.question: When parking next to a curb, you should use your turn signals:
questions.answerA: Only when pulling away from the curb.
questions.answerB: When pulling next to, but not away from, the curb.
questions.answerC: When pulling next to or away from the curb.
questions.explanation: Drivers should signal when pulling next to a curb or away from a curb.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No U-turn.
questions.answerB: No turning.
questions.answerC: No left turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you may not make a U-turn. You cannot turn around to go in the opposite direction at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: This sign is a warning that you are approaching:
questions.answerA: An intersection.
questions.answerB: A crosswalk.
questions.answerC: A railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: A round sign means you are approaching a railroad crossing. This sign is posted a few hundred feet in front of the tracks and tells drivers to slow down, look, listen, and prepare to stop.

questions.question: To help others see you when daylight begins to fade, you should use your:
questions.answerA: Parking lights.
questions.answerB: Low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Emergency flashers.
questions.explanation: As daylight begins to fade, turn on your low beams to help others see you. Only use your high beam headlights in an open area where no other drivers are present.

questions.question: You can help keep the driver behind you a safe distance away from your vehicle by:
questions.answerA: Driving 10 mph faster than the car behind you.
questions.answerB: Driving 10 mph slower than the car behind you.
questions.answerC: Maintaining a steady speed.
questions.explanation: It is not always easy to maintain a safe distance behind your vehicle. However, you can help keep the driver behind you a safe distance away from your vehicle by maintaining a steady speed and signaling turns, lane changes, and deceleration in advance.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you:
questions.answerA: Are approaching a railroad crossing and should prepare to stop.
questions.answerB: Will always stop at the upcoming railroad crossing.
questions.answerC: Should stop and wait for a signal before crossing the railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you are approaching a railroad crossing. You must look, listen, slow down, and prepare to stop. Wait for any trains to pass before you proceed.

questions.question: When you see this road sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep right.
questions.answerB: Keep left.
questions.answerC: Pass with caution.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that a divided highway is beginning and cars should keep to the right.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about driving speed is true?
questions.answerA: As your speed increases, the chance of a fatality increases.
questions.answerB: As your speed increases, so should your following distance.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: As driving speeds increase, the chance of a fatality in the case of a collision increases. If you are going faster than 80 miles per hour, you have almost no chance of living through a crash. The speed you drive affects your stopping distance, so you should increase your following distance as you increase your speed.

questions.question: When should drivers yield the right-of-way to pedestrians in a crosswalk?
questions.answerA: Only if the pedestrians first wave to the driver.
questions.answerB: Only if the pedestrians are not texting while walking.
questions.answerC: At all times.
questions.explanation: Bring your vehicle to a complete stop at a crosswalk to yield the right-of-way to any vehicle or pedestrian already in the intersection. You may carefully proceed if your lane is completely clear.

questions.question: What should you do with loose objects in your motor vehicle?
questions.answerA: Place them on the floor near the driver's seat.
questions.answerB: Secure them to avoid additional driving hazards.
questions.answerC: Place them on the dashboard.
questions.explanation: Make sure there are no loose objects in your vehicle that could hit and injure someone in the event of a sudden stop or crash. Make sure there are no objects on the floor that could roll under the brake pedal and prevent you from stopping the vehicle.

questions.question: If you are driving on a highway next to a single broken white line marking:
questions.answerA: You cannot cross the line to pass.
questions.answerB: You may cross the line to pass and change lanes.
questions.answerC: You may only cross the line to change lanes if you are in the left lane.
questions.explanation: White lines separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction. You may cross a dashed white line to pass or change lanes if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slippery when wet.
questions.answerB: Stop sign ahead.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: All roads are slippery and dangerous when wet. This sign warns of conditions that can cause a driver to lose control of a car. A driver should slow down when coming upon wet pavement because it takes longer to stop.

questions.question: Drivers may not park within ____ of a fire hydrant.
questions.answerA: 15 feet
questions.answerB: 20 feet
questions.answerC: 30 feet
questions.explanation: There are many areas where you cannot park. You should not park within 15 feet of a fire hydrant.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection with a flashing red light, you must:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop, yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians, then proceed.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed and proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Come to a complete stop and remain stopped as long as the light is red.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. When arriving at an intersection with a flashing red light, you must come to a full stop and proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: You should not start across an intersection if you know you will block the intersection when the light turns red:
questions.answerA: Under any circumstances.
questions.answerB: Unless you entered the intersection on a yellow light.
questions.answerC: Unless you entered the intersection on a green light.
questions.explanation: Even if the signal is green, you must not enter an intersection unless you can get completely across before the light turns red. If you block the intersection, you can be cited.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Upcoming downgrade or hill.
questions.answerB: Road construction area.
questions.answerC: Upcoming narrowing of roadway.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of a dangerous downgrade or hill ahead. The hill may be very long or steep, or it may have sharp curves.

questions.question: You are driving on a city street and see an emergency vehicle with flashing lights behind you. What should you do?
questions.answerA: Drive to the right edge of the road and slow down.
questions.answerB: Drive to the right edge of the road and stop.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane, slow down, and let it pass.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to any emergency vehicle that is using its siren and lights. Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle has passed. If you are within an intersection, drive through the intersection first and then stop.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Two-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Change in direction ahead.
questions.answerC: School zone and crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign informs drivers that they are leaving a divided roadway and approaching a two-way highway.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with airbags, the safest place for children age 12 and under to ride is in:
questions.answerA: The front seat.
questions.answerB: The back seat.
questions.answerC: The bed of a pick-up truck.
questions.explanation: While airbags provide supplemental protection for adults in the event of a crash, they pose a severe safety risk for children. Anyone age 12 or under should sit in the back seat of a vehicle with airbags.

questions.question: You are approaching a green traffic light and traffic is blocking the intersection. What is the best thing to do?
questions.answerA: Partially enter the intersection to establish your right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Don't enter the intersection until you can get completely across.
questions.answerC: Continue into the intersection and wait for traffic to clear.
questions.explanation: Even if your light is green, you must not enter an intersection unless you can get completely through the intersection before the light turns red. If you block the intersection, you can be cited.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No U-turn.
questions.answerB: Traffic signal ahead.
questions.answerC: Railroad ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that U-turns are prohibited.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection that is controlled by a flashing red traffic signal, you must:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop, yield to oncoming traffic or pedestrians, then proceed.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed and proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Come to a complete stop and remain stopped as long as the light is red.
questions.explanation: Treat a flashing red traffic signal the same as you would treat a stop sign. Come to a complete stop, yield to oncoming traffic or pedestrians, and proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers about:
questions.answerA: Upcoming intersections.
questions.answerB: Road construction.
questions.answerC: Road curves ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign is used to warn drivers about an upcoming curve to the right.

questions.question: If it is necessary to make an emergency stop while driving on an interstate, you should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn at passing cars to get their attention.
questions.answerB: Get out of your vehicle and flag down the first vehicle that passes.
questions.answerC: Pull off the road, turn on your emergency flashers, and stay in your vehicle, if you can.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the shoulder of the interstate or highway, turn on your emergency flashers to warn other drivers and stay inside your vehicle, if you can. The extremely high speed of traffic makes standing or walking along an interstate highway very dangerous.

questions.question: You should allow an extra cushion of space:
questions.answerA: When following a station wagon.
questions.answerB: When following a driver who cannot see the rear of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: When following a small passenger car.
questions.explanation: Drivers of trucks, buses, vans, or any vehicles pulling campers or trailers may not be able to see you if you are driving directly behind them. Increase your following distance when driving behind one of these vehicles. Additionally, large vehicles can block your view of the road, so increase your following distance to look around the sides of the vehicle and see the road ahead.

questions.question: Motorcycles, scooters, and mopeds are not easy to see; therefore, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down when driving.
questions.answerB: Make constant visual checks.
questions.answerC: Share a lane with a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles can be easily hidden in a vehicle’s blind spot or missed in a quick look due to their small size. Drivers of cars must always be alert and looking for motorcycles, mopeds, and scooters.

questions.question: Drivers should use their high beam headlights:
questions.answerA: Where there are no oncoming vehicles.
questions.answerB: Where there may be pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: High beam headlights let you see twice as far as low beam headlights. It is important to use high beams on unfamiliar roads, in construction areas, or where there may be people along the side of the road. Only use high beams if other vehicles are not nearby.

questions.question: You should not use your horn:
questions.answerA: When visibility ahead is limited.
questions.answerB: If you might hit another vehicle.
questions.answerC: Near blind pedestrians.
questions.explanation: When driving near a blind pedestrian, using your horn may be dangerous. Yield to the pedestrian and proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: At an intersection with stop signs on all corners, yield the right-of-way to any driver:
questions.answerA: On your left.
questions.answerB: Who arrived before you.
questions.answerC: Across from your vehicle.
questions.explanation: After coming to a full stop, vehicles should proceed through a four-way stop in the order in which they arrive to the intersection. If multiple vehicles arrive at the same time, the vehicle on the left must yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on the right.

questions.question: On a freeway, you should look farther ahead than you would on a city street:
questions.answerA: In order to see potential hazards early.
questions.answerB: Because it takes a quarter of a mile to stop your vehicle completely.
questions.answerC: Because it helps you keep up with traffic.
questions.explanation: On the freeway, be ready for changes in traffic conditions. Watch for signals from other drivers. Expect merging vehicles at on-ramps and interchanges and be prepared for rapid changes in road conditions and traffic flow.

questions.question: When driving at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Always use your high beams.
questions.answerB: Look directly at the headlights of an oncoming vehicle.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more hazardous than daytime driving because the lowered visibility makes it difficult to judge speed, distances, and other potential hazards. Increase your following distance to help prevent a potential collision if the vehicle in front of you should stop abruptly. Use your headlights when driving at night, following the rules for proper usage of high beams and low beams.

questions.question: Slowing down just to look at collisions or anything else out-of-the-ordinary:
questions.answerA: Causes traffic congestion.
questions.answerB: Prevents rear-end collisions.
questions.answerC: Improves traffic flow by preventing collisions.
questions.explanation: Avoid "rubbernecking," or slowing down to look at collisions or anything else out-of-the-ordinary. This helps to relieve traffic congestion.

questions.question: If oncoming headlights are blinding you while you are driving at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Look toward the right edge of the road.
questions.answerB: Switch your lights to high beams.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights on and off.
questions.explanation: If the headlights of an oncoming vehicle are blinding, glance toward the right edge of the road instead of looking directly ahead. This should keep your vehicle safely on the road until you pass the oncoming vehicle.

questions.question: If a motorist sees pedestrians in an upcoming crosswalk, what should the motorist do?
questions.answerA: Continue ahead. The motorist has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Wait for the pedestrians to cross the street.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right and go around the pedestrians.
questions.explanation: A driver must yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian within a crosswalk. The driver should wait until the intersection is clear to proceed.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You are approaching the end of a divided highway.
questions.answerB: You are approaching the beginning of a divided highway.
questions.answerC: The road will be slippery ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead. Keep to the right of the median divider.

questions.question: Double solid yellow lane markings mean that:
questions.answerA: Neither lane may pass.
questions.answerB: Both lanes may pass.
questions.answerC: The lane to the right may pass.
questions.explanation: Yellow lane markings indicate a separation of lanes where traffic is traveling in opposite directions. When you see double solid yellow lane markings, passing is prohibited from both directions.

questions.question: If the rear of your vehicle is skidding to the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Not turn your steering wheel.
questions.answerB: Turn your steering wheel to the left to correct the skid.
questions.answerC: Turn your steering wheel to the right to correct the skid.
questions.explanation: If you begin to skid on a wet or icy road, take your foot off the accelerator, stay off the brakes, and turn your steering wheel in the direction of the skid. However, if you have anti-lock brakes, you should apply your brakes firmly and steer straight ahead.

questions.question: When a car with bright headlights drives toward you at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop until the other driver passes.
questions.answerB: Look below their headlights.
questions.answerC: Glance toward the right edge of your lane.
questions.explanation: To avoid being blinded when driving at night, do not look directly at the headlights of oncoming cars. Instead, look toward the right edge of the road until the oncoming driver has passed.

questions.question: Drivers turning left must yield to:
questions.answerA: Oncoming vehicles traveling straight or turning right.
questions.answerB: Passing cars.
questions.answerC: No one in particular.
questions.explanation: Drivers making a left turn must yield to all vehicles approaching from the opposite direction. This includes bicycles and motorcycles.

questions.question: Roads are slippery after it first starts to rain. When the road is slippery, you should:
questions.answerA: Avoid making turns and stops while driving at high speeds.
questions.answerB: Test your tires' traction while going uphill.
questions.answerC: Decrease the distance you look ahead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: A wet, slippery road does not allow your tires the traction they need, so it is necessary to drive more slowly on a wet road than you would on a dry road. To reduce the risk of skidding, you should avoid fast turns or stops.

questions.question: If you have an argument with another person and you are angry, you should:
questions.answerA: Loudly play the radio while driving so you won’t think about your argument.
questions.answerB: Take a few minutes to cool off before driving.
questions.answerC: Drive on the interstate to let off steam.
questions.explanation: Your emotions affect your ability to drive safely. If you are overly angry, excited, afraid, worried, or depressed, you should give yourself time to calm down before operating a vehicle. You need to be able to mentally focus on driving without thinking about the things that made you upset.

questions.question: A broken yellow centerline indicates that:
questions.answerA: Passing is not permitted.
questions.answerB: Passing on the right is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.answerC: Passing on the left is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow centerline next to your side of the road indicates that traffic may cross the centerline to pass from your side of the road.

questions.question: If you see orange construction signs and cones on a freeway, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down because the lane ends ahead.
questions.answerB: Be prepared for workers and equipment ahead.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and maintain your current speed.
questions.explanation: As you enter a work zone, signs and message boards will warn you of workers, slow-moving equipment, and/or closed lanes ahead. You should reduce your speed and be prepared to slow down or stop.

questions.question: What is an important step in turning?
questions.answerA: Check traffic in all directions.
questions.answerB: Increase your speed.
questions.answerC: Always move to the left lane.
questions.explanation: When turning, you should look to the rear and both sides of your vehicle to ensure it is safe to proceed before making the turn. Adjust your speed to safely complete the turn.

questions.question: To be able to turn quickly, your hands must be:
questions.answerA: On opposite sides of the steering wheel.
questions.answerB: Next to each other on the top of the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: On the top and bottom of the steering wheel.
questions.explanation: Both hands should be placed on opposite sides of the steering wheel. This position is comfortable and promotes safe turning on high-speed roadways.

questions.question: When you see an emergency vehicle approaching while using its flashing lights, you must:
questions.answerA: Maintain your speed and stay in your lane until the vehicle has passed.
questions.answerB: Move into the right lane and drive slowly until the vehicle has passed.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the curb or edge of the road and stop until the vehicle has passed.
questions.explanation: If you see an emergency vehicle approaching while using its flashing lights, pull over to the right edge of the road and stop. Position yourself parallel to the curb. On one-way streets, drive toward the road edge nearest you.

questions.question: If there is no crosswalk and you see a pedestrian crossing your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the pedestrian can see you before proceeding.
questions.answerB: Cautiously drive around the pedestrian.
questions.answerC: Stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing.
