questions.explanation: Drivers must always yield the right-of-way to pedestrians in the roadway, even if there is not a marked crosswalk.

questions.question: A steady green traffic light at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Adjust your mirrors.
questions.answerC: You may continue through the intersection at a safe and reasonable speed, if it is clear to do so.
questions.explanation: A steady green traffic light indicates that the driver may continue through the intersection. The driver should yield to traffic or pedestrians already in the intersection and proceed when the intersection is clear.

questions.question: This sign is a:
questions.answerA: Yield sign.
questions.answerB: School crossing sign.
questions.answerC: Stop sign.
questions.explanation: A downward-facing triangular sign is always a yield sign. Drivers must be prepared to slow down or stop when approaching a yield sign.

questions.question: When arriving to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time as vehicles to your right and left, you should:
questions.answerA: Yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on your left.
questions.answerB: Yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on your right.
questions.answerC: Wait until there are no vehicles at the intersection before proceeding.
questions.explanation: If multiple vehicles arrive at the same time to an intersection that is not controlled by signs or signals, the driver on the right has the right-of-way. Drivers should then proceed in the order that they arrive to the intersection.

questions.question: If a traffic signal light is green and a police officer signals for you to stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Obey the officer.
questions.answerB: Obey the traffic signal.
questions.answerC: Do what the vehicle in front of you does.
questions.explanation: Drivers must obey any instructions given by a police officer, even if the instructions contradict laws, signs, signals, or markings that would otherwise apply.

questions.question: You should increase the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead when you:
questions.answerA: Are following a small passenger vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are being tailgated by another driver.
questions.answerC: Are driving more slowly than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: When being tailgated, create extra space in front of your vehicle and do not brake suddenly. Slow down gradually or merge into another lane to prevent a collision with the tailgater.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: One-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Merging traffic from the right.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign tells drivers to prepare to allow traffic to safely merge from the right.

questions.question: Interstate driving requires drivers to:
questions.answerA: Have the ability to safely drive at increased speeds.
questions.answerB: Be constantly alert.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Safe use of the interstate demands drivers be constantly alert and capable of driving at high speeds.

questions.question: If you find yourself in a skid:
questions.answerA: Brake lightly.
questions.answerB: Stay off the brakes.
questions.answerC: Brake abruptly.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to skid, do not use the brakes. Braking could make the skid worse.

questions.question: When entering or exiting a driveway, drivers:
questions.answerA: Have the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Should yield to pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Should honk at pedestrians to get them to move more quickly.
questions.explanation: Drivers crossing a sidewalk when entering or exiting a driveway, alley, or parking lot must yield to pedestrians. It is illegal to drive on a sidewalk except to cross it.

questions.question: What does this road sign indicate?
questions.answerA: Directions for children
questions.answerB: School zone ahead
questions.answerC: Playground area ahead
questions.explanation: Pentagonal signs indicate that you are in or are approaching a school zone and/or school crossing. Be aware of children when driving near a school zone and follow posted speed limits.

questions.question: You want to park downhill on a two-way road and there is no curb. Which way do you turn your front wheels?
questions.answerA: Straight ahead
questions.answerB: Right, toward the side of the road
questions.answerC: Left, toward the center of the road
questions.explanation: When parking facing downhill on a road with or without a curb, or when facing uphill on a road without a curb, turn your front wheels toward the edge of the road so your vehicle will roll away from traffic if the brakes fail. However, when parking uphill on a road with a curb, turn your wheels toward the center of the road so the vehicle will roll into the curb if the brakes fail.

questions.question: If you experience a tire blowout:
questions.answerA: Tap or pump the brakes.
questions.answerB: Slow down gradually and use your brakes lightly.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes firmly and quickly.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, you should slow down gradually by taking your foot off of the accelerator. Don't apply the brakes until the vehicle has slowed considerably.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: Reduction in lanes.
questions.explanation: A triangular red and white sign indicates that you must yield the right-of-way.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection with a flashing red light. You should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Slow down and drive carefully through the intersection.
questions.answerC: Come to a complete stop, check the traffic, and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to other traffic and pedestrians, and then proceed when it safe to do so.

questions.question: When parking your vehicle on any hill:
questions.answerA: One of your rear wheels should touch the curb.
questions.answerB: Use your parking brake and leave the vehicle in "park."
questions.answerC: Your front wheels should be parallel to the road, if there is no curb.
questions.explanation: When parking on a hill, you should always leave your vehicle in gear or in the "park" position. If there is no curb, you should turn your front wheels so that the vehicle will roll away from the center of the road if the brakes fail. If there is a curb, the front wheels should be turned toward it (if headed downhill) or away from and gently touching it (if headed uphill).

questions.question: To pass on a two-lane road, you should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn as you pass.
questions.answerB: Flash your headlights as you pass.
questions.answerC: Judge the distance to any oncoming vehicles.
questions.explanation: It can be hard to judge the speed of oncoming vehicles. They do not always seem to be coming as fast as they really are. Always be sure you can safely change lanes when passing on a two-lane street. If you are not sure of an oncoming vehicle's speed, wait to pass until the oncoming vehicle has passed and you are sure there is enough space for you to change lanes safely.

questions.question: You may cross double yellow lines to pass another vehicle if the:
questions.answerA: Vehicle in front of you moves to the right to let you pass.
questions.answerB: Yellow line next to your side of the road is broken.
questions.answerC: Yellow line next to the opposite side of the road is broken.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow line in the center of the road indicates that traffic next to the broken yellow line may pass, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No passing zone.
questions.answerB: Slow-moving vehicle.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: A triangular yellow sign with black lettering indicates a no passing zone. It will appear on the left side of a two-way, two-lane roadway at the beginning of an area where prohibitive pavement markings are also used.

questions.question: A distraction when driving is:
questions.answerA: Anything that causes evasive action while driving.
questions.answerB: Anything that takes your attention away from driving.
questions.answerC: Anything that causes you to pay more attention to driving.
questions.explanation: A distraction when driving is anything that takes your attention away from driving. Driver distractions may occur anytime and anywhere. Distracted driving can cause collisions, resulting in property damage, injury, and death.

questions.question: Give the right-of-way to any pedestrian who is:
questions.answerA: In a marked crosswalk.
questions.answerB: In any crosswalk or intersection.
questions.answerC: Crossing any street.
questions.explanation: Drivers must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians who are crossing the street in any marked or unmarked crosswalk. In the interest of safety, drivers should yield the right-of-way to people crossing any street.

questions.question: You want to make a right turn at the corner. A pedestrian with a guide dog is at the corner ready to cross the street in front of you. Before making your right turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn off your engine until the person crosses the street.
questions.answerB: Tell the pedestrian when to cross the street.
questions.answerC: Wait until the person crosses the street.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians using guide dogs or white canes (with or without a red tip) must be given the right-of-way at all times.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: No right turn.
questions.answerB: No U-turns.
questions.answerC: No left turn.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs provide notice to road users of traffic laws and must be obeyed. Where this sign is posted, making a right turn is prohibited.

questions.question: You are required to stop your vehicle:
questions.answerA: At any intersection where a police officer orders you to stop.
questions.answerB: Where there is a red traffic light.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: You must come to a complete stop at a steady or flashing red traffic light. You must always obey instructions given by officers directing traffic, regardless of any posted signs or traffic signals.

questions.question: Drivers should look ____ ahead of their vehicle when driving.
questions.answerA: Four seconds
questions.answerB: Seven seconds
questions.answerC: 10 seconds
questions.explanation: To avoid the need for last-minute braking or turning, look down the road at least 10 seconds ahead of your vehicle. By looking ahead and being ready to stop or change lanes if needed, you can drive more safely, save on fuel, and help keep traffic moving at a steady pace.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Trucks under 18,000 pounds are allowed.
questions.answerB: Hill ahead.
questions.answerC: Truck stop ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign indicates that there is a steep hill ahead. Slow down and be ready to shift to a lower gear to control your speed and protect your brakes from damage.

questions.question: What should a driver do when approaching a traffic control signal that is not in operation?
questions.answerA: Come to a full stop and yield the right-of-way before entering the intersection.
questions.answerB: If the intersection is clear, the driver does not need to stop.
questions.answerC: Drive quickly through the intersection to get out of the way of other vehicles.
questions.explanation: When traffic control signals are not working, a driver must always treat the intersection as an all-way stop and come to a complete stop, unless otherwise directed by law enforcement. The driver must then look and yield the right-of-way before entering the intersection.

questions.question: When should drivers use hand-over-hand steering?
questions.answerA: When turning the wheel during normal driving activity.
questions.answerB: When backing or when momentarily turning on blinkers, the radio, or windshield wipers.
questions.answerC: When turning the wheel at low speeds to make a sharp turn.
questions.explanation: When turning a sharp corner, turn the steering wheel by using the hand-over-hand technique. When you complete the turn, straighten out the steering wheel by hand.

questions.question: When may drivers stop in travel lanes?
questions.answerA: When they're lost.
questions.answerB: When they are dropping off a passenger.
questions.answerC: Never.
questions.explanation: Do not stop in travel lanes for any reason (confusion, breakdown, letting out a passenger, etc.). Keep moving until you can safely pull off the road.

questions.question: Various traffic control devices in construction and maintenance work areas are the color:
questions.answerA: Red.
questions.answerB: Orange.
questions.answerC: Yellow.
questions.explanation: Orange warning signs are used in and around work zones. Use special caution when you see orange signs, cones, or barriers on a roadway.

questions.question: An orange and red triangular sign on a vehicle always means:
questions.answerA: The vehicle has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Slow-moving vehicle.
questions.answerC: Shoulder work ahead.
questions.explanation: Slow-moving vehicles, such as farm tractors, road maintenance vehicles, and animal-drawn carts, display an orange and red triangle on the back.

questions.question: Streets and highways are most slippery:
questions.answerA: When it has been raining hard for several hours.
questions.answerB: When they are clean and dry.
questions.answerC: Just after it starts to rain.
questions.explanation: Driving during the first half hour of rainfall is dangerous because roadways become extremely slippery when the water mixes with oil and other chemicals on the road surfaces that have not yet washed away. Use extra caution when driving on slippery roads.

questions.question: South Dakota law requires ____ to use safety belts in a moving vehicle.
questions.answerA: Only operators
questions.answerB: Only children
questions.answerC: Children, front seat passengers, and operators
questions.explanation: The law requires all operators, front seat passengers, and children under the age of 18 to wear appropriate safety restraints while a vehicle is in motion. Small children should be secured in the rear seat.

questions.question: You hit a parked vehicle and can't find the owner. What must you do?
questions.answerA: Call your insurance company when you get home.
questions.answerB: Wait for the owner to return.
questions.answerC: Leave a note with your name and address on the parked vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you hit a parked vehicle or other property, you must leave a note with your name, phone number, and address securely attached to the vehicle or property that you hit.

questions.question: On a green arrow, you must:
questions.answerA: Yield to any vehicle, bicycle, or pedestrian in the intersection.
questions.answerB: Yield to pedestrians only in the intersection.
questions.answerC: Wait four seconds before proceeding.
questions.explanation: A green arrow means "go." You must turn in the direction the arrow is pointing after you yield to any vehicles, bicycles, or pedestrians who are still in the intersection.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Do not drink and drive.
questions.answerB: Slippery when wet.
questions.answerC: Road curves ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns that the roadway is slippery when wet.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerA: 0.05 percent.
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: If you are about to be hit from the rear, you should not:
questions.answerA: Release your seat belt.
questions.answerB: Brace yourself.
questions.answerC: Press your head against the head restraint.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle is hit from the rear while you are in forward motion, your body will be thrown backward. Brace yourself by pressing against the back of your seat and putting your head against the head restraint to prevent whiplash. Maintain a firm grip on the steering wheel and be ready to apply your brakes to avoid being pushed into another vehicle.

questions.question: Collisions are more likely to happen when:
questions.answerA: All vehicles are traveling at about the same speed.
questions.answerB: One lane of traffic is traveling faster than the other lanes.
questions.answerC: One vehicle is traveling faster or slower than the flow of traffic.
questions.explanation: Collisions are more likely to happen when one driver moves faster or slower than the other vehicles on the road. Driving faster than other traffic increases your chance of being involved in a collision. Driving more slowly than other traffic is also dangerous because it can increase the risk of a rear-end collision with your vehicle or cause other drivers to swerve to avoid hitting you.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Crossroad ahead.
questions.answerB: Merge.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a crossroad ahead.

questions.question: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Challenge them.
questions.answerB: Get out of their way.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.explanation: Drivers must respect and cooperate with all other road users and conform to specific rules in order to maintain order and to avoid crashes. When encountering an aggressive driver, it is safest to just get out of their way. Always avoid competing with other drivers.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: Falling rocks
questions.answerB: Trucks use second gear
questions.answerC: Steep hill
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that you are approaching a steep hill. Slow down and be ready to shift to a lower gear to control your speed and protect your brakes from damage.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You should stop for other traffic.
questions.answerB: Traffic is entering from another road and you should allow additional space for drivers to merge safely into the flow of traffic.
questions.answerC: Traffic is entering from another road and you should keep right.
questions.explanation: This sign alerts you to the possibility of traffic merging into the main stream of travel. After checking to your side and rear, you should move into another lane, if possible, to allow merging motorists a clear path.

questions.question: When driving in fog or mist, never put your headlights on the high beam setting because:
questions.answerA: The light will reflect back into your eyes.
questions.answerB: Approaching vehicles might not see you.
questions.answerC: Vehicles behind you may follow too closely.
questions.explanation: In foggy or misty conditions, you should not use your headlights on their high beam setting because the light will be reflected back into your eyes.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers that:
questions.answerA: The right lane is ending and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerB: The road curves ahead.
questions.answerC: There are upcoming intersections.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers that the number of lanes is reduced ahead and that traffic should merge left.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No right turn.
questions.answerB: Right turn on red light permitted with caution.
questions.answerC: All traffic must turn right at next intersection.
questions.explanation: Signs with a red circle and diagonal line over a black symbol indicate the the action represented by the symbol is prohibited. In this case, the sign indicates that right turns are prohibited.

questions.question: Before returning to your original lane after passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Beep your horn.
questions.answerB: See both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Flash your headlights.
questions.explanation: When passing is permitted, look for both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror. Only then may you safely return to your original lane.

questions.question: If you see a pedestrian using a guide dog or carrying a white cane:
questions.answerA: The pedestrian must yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: You must yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn to let them know you are there.
questions.explanation: Blind or partially blind pedestrians may carry a white cane or use the assistance of a guide dog. You must yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian with a guide dog or a white cane.

questions.question: While driving at night, a vehicle coming toward you has its high beams on, making it hard for you to see the road ahead. You should:
questions.answerA: Look ahead toward the left edge of your lane.
questions.answerB: Look ahead toward the right edge of your lane.
questions.answerC: Look straight ahead in your lane.
questions.explanation: If an oncoming driver fails to dim their high beams, you should avoid looking directly at the headlights. Instead, look toward the right edge of your lane and watch the oncoming vehicle out of the corner of your eye.

questions.question: Stopping distances and the severity of collisions:
questions.answerA: Decrease as a vehicle's speed increases.
questions.answerB: Are not affected by a vehicle's speed.
questions.answerC: Increase as a vehicle's speed increases.
questions.explanation: Excessive vehicle speed can have disastrous effects. As a vehicle's speed increases, the potential impact of a collision also increases, elevating the possibility of serious injury and death. Increase your following distance as your speed increases to ensure that you will be able to stop safely if needed.

questions.question: The best way to avoid a dangerous situation while driving is to:
questions.answerA: Know what is happening around your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Turn off the radio.
questions.answerC: Always keep your eyes focused ahead of your car.
questions.explanation: Always be aware of what is happening around your vehicle. Constantly observing your surroundings to the front, sides, and rear of your vehicle will help you see problems that may require you to change speed or roadway position.

questions.question: Drivers must use their parking brake:
questions.answerA: Only when parked on an incline.
questions.answerB: Only when parked in a parking lot.
questions.answerC: Every time they park.
questions.explanation: Always set your parking brake when you park. Leave the vehicle in gear if it has a manual transmission or in “Park” if it has an automatic transmission.

questions.question: When being passed by another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Brake hard.
questions.answerB: Maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.explanation: When being passed, you must yield to the passing vehicle and not increase your speed. Allow the vehicle to safely merge back into your lane.

questions.question: You check your blind spots:
questions.answerA: By looking in your side mirrors.
questions.answerB: By turning your head and looking over your shoulders.
questions.answerC: By looking in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Blind spots are areas around your vehicle that you cannot see by using your mirrors. Check your blind spots by turning your head and glancing over your shoulders.

questions.question: Always stop before crossing railroad tracks when:
questions.answerA: There isn't room on the other side for you to completely cross the tracks.
questions.answerB: The railroad crossing is located in a city or town that has frequent train traffic.
questions.answerC: You are transporting two or more young children in a passenger vehicle.
questions.explanation: Expect a train on any track, at any time, traveling in either direction. If you need to stop after crossing the tracks, wait until you can completely cross the tracks before proceeding. Make sure your vehicle clears the tracks before you stop.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: Driving too slowly is not an unsafe practice.
questions.answerB: Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous.
questions.answerC: The speed at which you drive a vehicle does not affect safety.
questions.explanation: Driving too slowly can be dangerous because it may cause drivers behind you to become frustrated and make dangerous moves to pass you. It is safest to drive with the flow of traffic, within the legal speed limit.

questions.question: Which of these is a safe driving technique?
questions.answerA: Using your high beam lights in the fog.
questions.answerB: Staring at the road ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Checking your rearview mirrors frequently.
questions.explanation: To stay aware of hazards, you should scan the road and check your rearview mirrors every two to five seconds. Constantly staring at just the road ahead of you is dangerous. If you must drive in foggy conditions, you should use your low beam headlights, not your high beam headlights.

questions.question: When traveling at high speeds, drivers should signal ____ before making a turn.
questions.answerA: Two seconds
questions.answerB: Four to five seconds
questions.answerC: 10 seconds
questions.explanation: Drivers must use their turn signals before changing lanes or making a turn. Drivers traveling at high speeds should signal four to five seconds before moving to the left or right.

questions.question: A reflective orange triangle on the back of a vehicle indicates that:
questions.answerA: It is a slow-moving vehicle.
questions.answerB: It is an ambulance.
questions.answerC: It is a school bus.
questions.explanation: A reflective orange triangle on the rear of a vehicle means the vehicle often moves at speeds of 25 mph or slower. You may see this decal on construction equipment, farm vehicles, and horse-drawn wagons or carriages.

questions.question: When you see this yellow sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop at the crosswalk.
questions.answerB: Stop at the crosswalk until a crossing guards signals for you to go.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop if children are in the crosswalk.
questions.explanation: A five-sided sign indicates that you are near a school. Be aware and stop if children are in the crosswalk.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The roadway ends ahead.
questions.answerB: Drivers must bear either right or left.
questions.answerC: A four-way intersection is ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that they are arriving upon a fork in the road and they must bear either right or left.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about drugs and driving?
questions.answerA: Any prescription drug is safe to use if you don't feel drowsy.
questions.answerB: Even over-the-counter drugs can impair your driving.
questions.answerC: Only illegal drugs can impair your driving.
questions.explanation: Legal prescription and over-the-counter drugs can impair your ability to drive, including drugs taken for colds, hay fever, allergies, or to calm nerves or muscles. It is illegal to drive while under the influence of any drug that impairs your ability to drive safely; this law does not differentiate between illegal, prescription, or over-the-counter drugs.

questions.question: Vehicles are required to be covered by liability insurance:
questions.answerA: Only when used on an interstate.
questions.answerB: Only when operated by a minor.
questions.answerC: At all times.
questions.explanation: South Dakota state law requires all vehicles to be properly registered and insured at all times. Drivers must keep proof of responsibility in the vehicle.

questions.question: Head restraints should be:
questions.answerA: Adjusted to contact the back of the head.
questions.answerB: Removed from the seats, if possible.
questions.answerC: Anywhere, as they have no effect on either the driver or passengers.
questions.explanation: Head restraints are designed to prevent whiplash if your vehicle is hit from behind. They should be adjusted to contact the back of your head.

questions.question: Any amount of alcohol in the blood may affect a driver's:
questions.answerA: Right-of-way privileges.
questions.answerB: Judgment and physical coordination.
questions.answerC: Knowledge.
questions.explanation: A driver’s ability to safely operate a vehicle may be impaired at any BAC level, even a level lower than the legal limit. Any amount of alcohol can affect one’s judgment and physical coordination. Driving under the influence of even a small amount of alcohol can lead to criminal charges.

questions.question: This white sign means you should not pass other vehicles:
questions.answerA: Until after you pass the sign.
questions.answerB: Unless it seems safe to do so.
questions.answerC: For any reason.
questions.explanation: A white rectangular sign indicates that you must obey the stated rule. This sign means that drivers should not pass other vehicles for any reason.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: Check your side mirror and look over your shoulder to make sure the lane is clear.
questions.answerB: Check the inside rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should check your side mirrors and look over your shoulder to make sure it is safe to proceed.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: School crossing.
questions.answerB: School zone.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign marks the presence of a crosswalk. Be alert to any pedestrians that may be crossing the roadway.

questions.question: When making a left turn, you should not:
questions.answerA: Signal to other drivers.
questions.answerB: Cut the corner.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: When turning left, you should slow down and activate your turn signal before making the turn. Be careful not to cut the corner short, as this may interfere with traffic.

questions.question: When you want to change lanes, you should never:
questions.answerA: Move into another lane while within an intersection.
questions.answerB: Check your blind spot by looking over your shoulder.
questions.answerC: Check for other drivers moving into the same lane.
questions.explanation: You should never change lanes within an intersection. Before changing lanes, always look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. Be alert to other drivers moving into the same lane.

questions.question: When a school bus is stopped on the road ahead to load or unload children, you must:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop until all the children have left the bus.
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop until the red lights stop flashing and the stop arm is withdrawn.
questions.answerC: Change lanes, drive slowly, and pass the bus cautiously.
questions.explanation: When a school bus is stopped on the road ahead with its lights flashing and its stop arm extended, you must come to a complete stop and wait to proceed until the lights have stopped flashing and the stop arm is withdrawn. Even after the bus begins to move again, do not proceed until you are sure there are no children crossing the road ahead of you.

questions.question: If weather or light conditions require you to have your lights on while driving:
questions.answerA: Use your parking lights.
questions.answerB: Use your high beams.
questions.answerC: Use your low beams.
questions.explanation: Use your low beam headlights when driving in foggy, snowy, or rainy conditions. Light from high beam headlights will reflect back, causing glare and making it even more difficult to see ahead.

questions.question: If your vehicle begins to skid, you should:
questions.answerA: Ease up on the gas pedal.
questions.answerB: Brake as hard as possible.
questions.answerC: Turn off the ignition.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to skid, release the accelerator or brake pedal to regain vehicle balance. Steer in the direction of the skid to regain control of the vehicle.

questions.question: What can you do to reduce road rage?
questions.answerA: Always signal your intention when changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Talk on your cell phone while driving.
questions.answerC: Use your horn frequently.
questions.explanation: To do your part to prevent road rage, you should follow laws, signs, signals, and pavement markings. Always signal your intention when changing lanes.

questions.question: You are approaching an intersection where a traffic signal is displaying a steady yellow light. If you have not already entered the intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to beat the red light.
questions.answerB: Reduce you speed and proceed carefully through the intersection.
questions.answerC: Come to a safe stop.
questions.explanation: At an intersection controlled by a steady yellow light, you should bring your vehicle to a safe stop. If you are already within the intersection when the light changes from green to yellow, continue through the intersection at a safe speed.

questions.question: If you are continually being passed on the right and the left while driving in the center lane of an expressway, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center lane.
questions.answerB: Move to the lane on your right.
questions.answerC: Move to the lane on your left.
questions.explanation: If a road has four or more lanes with two-way traffic, drive in the right lanes unless you are passing or turning left. If you are on an interstate highway and are driving below the speed of the flow of traffic, use the right lane.

questions.question: If it feels like your tires have lost contact with the surface of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down by shifting into a lower gear.
questions.answerB: Ease your foot off the gas pedal.
questions.answerC: Slow down by pumping the brakes quickly and firmly.
questions.explanation: If it feels like your tires have lost contact with the surface of the road, you should ease your foot off the gas pedal and stay off the brakes. Do not try to stop or turn until your tires are gripping the road again.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, it is safe to return to your lane if you:
questions.answerA: Cannot see the vehicle directly to your right.
questions.answerB: See the vehicle’s headlights in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Have passed the other vehicle’s front bumper.
questions.explanation: Before returning to your original lane after passing, you must make sure you are not dangerously close to the vehicle you have just passed. When you can see both of the vehicle's headlights in your rearview mirror, you may have enough room to return to the lane.

questions.question: Hydroplaning occurs when tires ride on a thin film of water instead of on the road. To prevent hydroplaning in wet weather, you should:
questions.answerA: Put on your cruise control to maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerB: Slow down.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder of the road as soon as it starts to rain.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is caused by driving too fast on a wet road. Slow down when driving on wet pavement to prevent hydroplaning.

questions.question: When approaching a stopped school bus that has its stop signal arm extended and its lights flashing, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop and wait to proceed.
questions.answerB: Honk their horn before passing the bus on its left.
questions.answerC: Continue driving when they think most kids are done exiting the bus.
questions.explanation: When you are approaching a school bus that is stopped with its stop arm extended and lights flashing, come to a complete stop. Remain stopped until the stop signal is retracted and the flashing lights are turned off.

questions.question: If your vehicle starts to lose traction because of water on the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive at a constant speed to gain better traction.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes firmly to prevent your vehicle from sliding.
questions.answerC: Slow down gradually and not apply the brakes.
questions.explanation: When driving in heavy rain at speeds as low as 30 mph, your tires may lose all contact with the road and instead ride up on a layer of water above the surface of the road. This is called "hydroplaning." If your vehicle starts to hydroplane, slow down gradually and do not apply the brakes.

questions.question: At a railroad crossing, you must:
questions.answerA: Watch for vehicles that must stop at all railroad crossings (school buses, trucks carrying hazardous materials, etc.).
questions.answerB: Watch for multiple trains.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: You must approach all railroad crossings with extreme caution and cross only when you know that no train is coming from either direction. Be aware of vehicles that must stop at all railroad crossings, such as school buses and trucks carrying hazardous materials.

questions.question: When making a right turn, you should not:
questions.answerA: Signal to other drivers.
questions.answerB: Swing too wide for your lane.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: When turning right, you should slow down and activate your turn signal before making the turn. Be careful not to turn too wide for your lane, as this may interfere with traffic.

questions.question: Which of the following blocks the smooth flow of traffic?
questions.answerA: Slowing down to look at collision scene.
questions.answerB: Avoiding unnecessary lane changes.
questions.answerC: Using public transportation instead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Rubbernecking (the practice of slowing down to look at collisions or other out-of-the-ordinary things) contributes to traffic congestion and should be avoided.

questions.question: If your car's suspension is bad, it can cause:
questions.answerA: Vehicle control problems.
questions.answerB: Squealing brakes.
questions.answerC: Slack in the steering.
questions.explanation: Your suspension helps you control your vehicle and provides a comfortable ride over varying road surfaces. If your vehicle bounces a lot after driving over a bump, or is generally hard to control, you may need new suspension parts.

questions.question: Work zone barriers, drums, cones, and signs are used to:
questions.answerA: Make drivers angry about slow traffic.
questions.answerB: Inconvenience drivers.
questions.answerC: Keep traffic out of hazardous work zones.
questions.explanation: Work zones on highways have become increasingly dangerous places for both workers and drivers. When approaching a work zone, watch for materials such as cones, barrels, signs, large vehicles, and workers in brightly colored vests to warn you and direct you.

questions.question: If a tire suddenly blows out while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Grip the steering wheel firmly, slow down, and exit the traffic lane.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes rapidly.
questions.answerC: Brake hard and steer toward the right edge of the roadway.
questions.explanation: If you experience a sudden tire blowout, do not panic. Grasp the steering wheel firmly and take your foot off the accelerator to allow the vehicle to roll to a stop. Lightly apply the breaks when it is safe to do so. Do not move to the shoulder of the road until the car has slowed considerably.

questions.question: If your wheels drop off the roadway or pavement edge, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait until it is safe to do so, then gradually re-enter the roadway.
questions.answerB: Turn back onto the roadway immediately.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: If your wheels drop off the roadway or pavement edge, do not attempt to turn back onto the roadway immediately. Instead, reduce your speed, check traffic, and gradually turn back onto the roadway when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Curves ahead.
questions.answerB: Divided highway starts.
questions.answerC: Divided highway ends.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns that the divided highway ends ahead. Prepare to change lanes or shift lane position.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you can check your blind spot by:
questions.answerA: Using the inside rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Turning your head and looking over your shoulder.
questions.answerC: Using your side mirror.
questions.explanation: Even if your vehicle is properly equipped with mirrors, there are blind spots that cannot be seen by using the mirrors. Before changing lanes, look over your shoulder to check these areas.

questions.question: A solid yellow line on your side of the centerline means:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: Traffic light ahead.
questions.answerC: Do not pass.
questions.explanation: Solid yellow lines on two-lane roads indicate zones where passing is prohibited. If a solid yellow line appears next to a broken yellow line, drivers in the lane nearest to the solid yellow line may not pass. In some instances, both yellow lines will be solid, indicating that it is not safe to pass from either direction.

questions.question: Accumulating ____ on your license within a 12-month period will result in the suspension of your license.
questions.answerA: 15 points
questions.answerB: 10 points
questions.answerC: Eight points
questions.explanation: Certain offenses committed while driving will count against a driver in South Dakota's system of suspending driver licenses. If a driver accrues 15 points or more within a 12-month period, their license will be suspended. Lengths of suspension vary based on how many offenses the driver has committed.

questions.question: Which of the following driving skills are affected by the use of alcohol and/or drugs?
questions.answerA: Alertness and concentration.
questions.answerB: Reaction time and coordination.
questions.answerC: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Any amount of alcohol acts as a depressant, slowing the function of the nervous system. It will reduce a person's alertness and ability to concentrate, increase their reaction time, and drastically reduce their coordination.
